{{For|other people of this name|David Jensen (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{BLP sources|date=March 2011}}
'''David Alan''' "'''Kid'''" '''Jensen''' (born 4 July 1950) is a Canadian-born British [[radio DJ]].
==Early career== Born into a [[Danish people|Danish]] family residing in [[Victoria, British Columbia]], Jensen began his career in his home country at the age of sixteen playing jazz and classical music. He then joined [[Radio Luxembourg (English)|Radio Luxembourg]] at the age of eighteen in November 1968, joining Paul Kay, [[Paul Burnett]], [[Noel Edmonds]] and Tony Prince as the resident DJ team. His recruitment was part of the "all-live" initiative, bringing to an end most of the pre-recorded shows.
His initial slot was 1{{nbsp}}am to 3{{nbsp}}am Monday to Thursday, and 7{{nbsp}}pm to 9{{nbsp}}pm Sunday evenings, but was quickly promoted at the start of 1969 to an earlier slot, mostly starting at 9{{nbsp}}pm. Being only 18 years old, Paul Burnett affectionately called him the "kid" and the name "Kid" Jensen was being widely used in newspaper listings by February 1969. From May 1970 he presented a popular progressive rock show, typically broadcast at midnight or 1{{nbsp}}am, later billed as "Dimensions" which resulted in a big increase in listeners to this slot.
By 1974, Jensen was becoming a TV personality in Britain, hosting pop shows on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]], and in the mid-1970s he worked for the then-new [[Radio Trent]] (now [[Capital East Midlands]]) in [[Nottingham]], one of the first legal, land-based commercial radio stations in the UK. During the early part of his career he was billed as "Kid Jensen" and did not use his given name professionally until 1980.
==Broadcasting career==
===BBC Radio 1=== In 1976 he joined the BBC's pop network, [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]], initially hosting a Saturday morning show from 10{{nbsp}}am to midday, but sitting in for many other DJs, and eventually graduating to a weekday late afternoon/early evening show in the spring of 1978 from 4:30 to 7:00{{nbsp}}pm. He kept his profile high through regular appearances presenting ''[[Top of the Pops]]'', and championed many acts who went on to achieve huge commercial success, notably [[The Police]] and [[Gary Numan]].
In September 1980, Jensen left the BBC to work for the [[Turner Broadcasting System]] [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|WTBS cable superstation]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia]] where he was host of the 10:00{{nbsp}}pm nightly news, but he returned a year later, presenting the Radio 1 weekday evening show from 8{{snd}}10{{nbsp}}pm; later extended to run from 7{{snd}}10{{nbsp}}pm. Soon afterwards he dropped the "Kid" name, although he would still be popularly known by it for many years to come. His mid-evening show was dominated by indie-rock, but also featured interviews with mainstream acts such as [[Duran Duran]], and was the first show to champion [[Frankie Goes to Hollywood]], before their commercial success. He remained a regular ''Top of the Pops'' presenter and struck up a famous partnership with [[John Peel]]. He also wrote a pop column for the ''[[Daily Mirror]]''.
===Capital Radio=== In 1984, Jensen quit Radio 1 and joined London's [[Capital London|Capital FM]], presenting the weekday mid-morning show (replacing Michael Aspel); moving to weekday drivetime in 1987. In addition to his weekday shows he also presented the weekly ''[[The Network Chart Show]]'', the UK's first syndicated commercial radio show which originally went out every Sunday between 5{{nbsp}}pm and 7{{nbsp}}pm, competing directly with Radio 1's [[The Official Chart|Top 40]] show.
While presenting the ''Network Chart'', Jensen became [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]'s unofficial "face" of pop music, presenting pop shows such as ''[[The Roxy (TV)|The Roxy]]'' (an attempt to compete with ''Top of the Pops''). He continued to comment regularly on pop-related stories in [[ITN]] and [[Sky News]] bulletins for some time after he left the ''Network Chart'' in 1993, when he was replaced by [[Neil Fox (broadcaster)|Neil Fox]]. Jensen continued to present the weekday drivetime show on Capital FM until 1998.
He also presented various children's programmes including ''Worldwise'' and ''Popquest''.
===Recent years=== In 1998, Jensen joined rival London FM station, [[Heart 106.2]], presenting the weekday drivetime show from 4{{nbsp}}pm to 7{{nbsp}}pm. He also presented a Sunday afternoon CD chart show called Kid Jensen's CD Countdown which was produced by [[Blue Revolution]] and networked on [[Birmingham]]'s [[100.7 Heart FM]] and various other stations.
In 2002, Jensen returned to Capital and was heard on its oldies service [[Gold (radio)|Capital Gold]]. First presenting the Monday–Thursday late night show from 10{{nbsp}}pm{{snd}}1{{nbsp}}am, before taking over the weekday mid-morning slot in February 2003, then the breakfast show, (co-hosted with Erika North). Jensen later moved to the late morning slot 10{{nbsp}}am{{snd}}1{{nbsp}}pm. Jensen teamed up with Capital Radio Producer Craig Kingham to present the Saturday morning show. Jensen left Gold in December 2010.
In September 2008, Jensen hosted the evening show of [[Planet Rock (radio station)|Planet Rock]] (7-11pm) as a stand-in for [[Nicky Horne]]. He also hosted Planet Rock's Sunday Morning show, "Another Dimension", and co-hosted with [[Rick Wakeman]] on Saturday mornings until December 2010 and briefly hosted the Saturday morning 10{{nbsp}}am{{snd}}1{{nbsp}}pm show on his own, until he left the station in April 2011.
Jensen joined [[Smooth Radio]] in April 2011 to present an afternoon show.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://radiotoday.co.uk/news.php?extend.6821.17|title= Emma B joins Smooth Radio|publisher= |work= Radio Today|date= 14 March 2011|accessdate= 27 March 2011|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317011326/http://radiotoday.co.uk/news.php?extend.6821.17|archivedate= 17 March 2011|df= dmy-all}}</ref> In April 2012, he took over the Smooth Drive Home slot (Mondays to Friday, 4pm – 8pm) from [[Carlos (DJ)|Carlos]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/03/further-schedule-changes-for-smooth-radio/ |title=Smooth Radio adds Donny Osmond to line-up |publisher=Radio Today |date=21 March 2012 |accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> Jensen also hosted a two-hour retro chart show on Smooth Radio on Sunday evenings. Smooth was acquired by Global Radio in 2013. Following a studio and business move to Global headquarters in Leicester Square, Jensen was dropped from the schedules on 19 December 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/12/kid-jensen-pat-sharp-leave-smooth-radio/ |title=David Jensen leaves Smooth |publisher=Radio Today |date=19 December 2013 |accessdate=19 December 2013}}</ref>
He was a co-presenter (off-screen) of the TV programme Gillette World Sports Special, alongside [[Mark Webster (journalist)|Mark Webster]].
==Personal life== Jensen is married to wife Guðrún and they have three children and seven grandchildren. Their youngest son, [[Viktor Jensen|Viktor]], a successful racing driver, both competed in and was also a National Class winner in the 2007 British and International Formula 3 Championship. Jensen also founded the Kid Jensen Racing team that briefly raced in the [[International Formula 3000|Formula 3000]] championship, which won one race at the hands of [[Nicolas Minassian]] in [[1999 International Formula 3000 season|1999]] at [[Silverstone Circuit|Silverstone]].
A [[Freemasonry|Freemason]], he is a member of Chelsea Lodge No. 3098, the membership of which is made up of entertainers.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.chelsea-lodge.org.uk/ | title=Chelsea Lodge No. 3098 100 Years 1905-2005}}</ref>
In 2010 he became a [[Freeman of the City of London]] and was inducted into the UK Radio Hall of Fame.
Jensen is a fan of [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], is chairman of the Crystal Palace F.C. Vice-President's Club, and also acted as ambassador for the CPFC 2010 consortium during the purchase of the club from administrators.
It was announced on 16 January 2018 that Jensen had decided to go public about living with [[Parkinson's disease]] (PD for the previous five years. In March 2018, Irish radio presenter [[Gareth O'Callaghan]] announced to listeners of Neil Prendeville's [[Cork's Red FM]] show that he had himself developed Parkinson's, mentioning that, prior to his diagnosis, he had read a ''[[Daily Mail]]'' article in which Jensen discussed his experience and how he (O'Callaghan) could relate to it.<ref>{{cite news|first=Olivia|last=Kelleher|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/entertainment/gareth-ocallaghan-to-step-down-from-radio-after-being-diagnosed-with-incurable-and-rare-disease-862971.html|title=Gareth O'Callaghan to step down from radio after being diagnosed with 'incurable' and rare disease|work=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=18 August 2018|accessdate=18 August 2018|quote=The former 2FM DJ, who is also a successful writer, said he was diagnosed after a series of conundrums came together. He read an article about Parkinson's in the Daily Mail in which DJ David Jensen spoke of the condition. Gareth realised he could have taken the DJ's name out and inserted his given the similarities of the symptoms.}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.signal2.co.uk/on-air/kid-jensens-flashback-40/ Kid Jensen's Flashback 40 on Signal 2] *[http://www.radiorewind.co.uk/radio1/david_jensen_page.htm Radio Rewind - David Jensen]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Doug Kershaw | image = Dougkershaw.jpg | caption = Doug Kershaw playing the fiddle at the 2009 [[Festivals Acadiens et Créoles]]. | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Douglas James Kershaw | birth_place = Tiel Ridge in [[Cameron Parish, Louisiana]], US<ref name="fiddle">{{cite web|last=Simmons|first=Michael|title=Doug Kershaw: The "Real Deal" in Cajun Fiddle|url=http://www.fiddle.com/Articles.page?Index=23&ArticleID=18818|publisher=Fiddle.com|date=March 1, 2003|accessdate=2014-08-11}}</ref><ref name="McCall-p263">{{cite book|last1=McCall|first1=Michael|last2=Paxman|first2=Bob|title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2012|page=263|isbn=978-0195395631}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1936|01|24}}<ref name="fiddle" /><ref name="McCall-p263" /> | instrument = [[Fiddle]], [[Cajun accordion]], [[Guitar]] | origin = United States | genre = [[Cajun music]], [[country music|country]], [[folk music|folk]] | occupation = Musician, songwriter | years_active = 1948–present | website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20071107230721/http://www.grabow.biz/Country/DougKershaw.htm Website] }}
'''Douglas James Kershaw''' (born January 24, 1936<ref name="fiddle" /><ref name="McCall-p263" />) is an American [[Musical styles (violin)#Fiddle|fiddle]] player, singer and songwriter from [[Louisiana]]. Active since 1948, he began his career as part of the duo [[Rusty and Doug]], along with his brother, [[Rusty Kershaw]]. He had an extensive solo career that included fifteen albums and singles that charted on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. He is also a member of the [[Louisiana Music Hall of Fame]], being inducted in 2009.
== Early life == Born in an unincorporated community called Tiel Ridge in [[Cameron Parish, Louisiana|Cameron Parish]], Kershaw did not learn English until the age of eight. By that time, he had mastered the fiddle, which he played from the age of five, and was on his way to teaching himself to play 28 instruments.<ref name = "CMT">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/kershaw_doug/bio.jhtml |title=Doug Kershaw Bio |publisher=Cmt.com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-17}}</ref> His first gig was at a local bar, the Bucket of Blood, where he was accompanied by his mother on guitar.<ref name="LouisianaRocks">{{cite book|last1=Aswell|first1=Tom|title=Louisiana Rocks!: The True Genesis of Rock and Roll|date=2013|publisher=Pelican Publishing|isbn=9781455607839|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BSHTGsnI8skC&pg=PA222&dq=%22Doug+Kershaw%22+%2B+%22Bucket+of+Blood%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiproSWmunVAhWBJCYKHSlEBi8Q6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=%22Doug%20Kershaw%22%20%2B%20%22Bucket%20of%20Blood%22&f=false|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref>
Kershaw became interested in Cajun music during parties his parents would host on the family's [[houseboat]] in Louisiana, where he first heard Cajun bands playing the music.
=="Doug and Rusty"== Doug grew up surrounded by [[Cajun music|Cajun]] fiddle and [[accordion]] music. After teaching his brother, Rusty, to play guitar, he formed a band, the Continental Playboys, with Rusty and older brother Nelson "Peewee" Kershaw in 1948.<ref name="LouisianaRocks"/> With the departure of Peewee from the group, in the early 1950s, [[Rusty & Doug]] continued to perform as a duo. In 1955, when Kershaw was nineteen, he and Rusty performed on the ''[[Louisiana Hayride]]'' [[KWKH]] radio broadcast in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]], Louisiana.<ref name="Stabler-p233">{{cite book|last=Stambler|first=Irwin|title=Country Music: The Encyclopedia|year=2000|publisher=St. Martin's Griffin|edition=3rd|page=233|isbn=978-0312264871}}</ref> The two also performed at the WWVA Jamboree (later renamed [[Jamboree U.S.A.]]), in [[Wheeling, West Virginia|Wheeling]], West Virginia.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dregni|first1=Michael|title=Rockabilly: The Twang Heard 'Round the World: The Illustrated History|date=2011|publisher=Voyageur Press|isbn=9780760340622|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=06VWZ69WBAEC&pg=PA144&dq=%22Doug+Kershaw%22+%2B+%22WWVA+jamboree%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj14ozNm-nVAhVLMSYKHUZhCKMQ6AEIKzAB#v=onepage&q=%22Doug%20Kershaw%22%20%2B%20%22WWVA%20jamboree%22&f=false|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref>
Although the brothers initially sang in French, [[J. D. "Jay" Miller]], owner of the [[Feature Records]] label, persuaded them to incorporate songs in English into their repertoire. In 1955, Doug and Rusty recorded their first single, "So Lovely, Baby." Released on the Hickory label, the tune went to number 14 on the country music charts. Later that same year, Doug and Rusty were invited to become cast members of the ''[[Louisiana Hayride]]'' cast. The Kershaws appeared at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] and became regular members of the Opry cast the following year.<ref name = "CMT" /><ref>{{cite web | title = Opry Timeline – 1950s | url = http://www.opry.com/about/Timeline_1950.html | date = | publisher = Opry.com | accessdate = July 10, 2012}}</ref>
Despite the demands of his music career, Doug enrolled in [[McNeese State University]], in [[Lake Charles, Louisiana]], where he earned an [[undergraduate degree]] in Mathematics. At the peak of their early career, in 1958, Doug and Rusty both enlisted in the [[United States Army]]. They devoted their attention to the military until their discharge three years later.<ref name="LouisianaRocks"/>
== "Louisiana Man" and solo career == After fulfilling their military obligation, the two brothers recorded "[[Louisiana Man]]", an autobiographical song that Doug had written while in the Army. The song not only sold millions of copies but over the years has come to be considered a standard of modern Cajun music.<ref name="Woodstra-p255">{{cite book|last=Woodstra|first=Chris|title=All Music Guide to Country: The Experts' Guide to the Best Country Recordings|publisher=Backbeat Books|edition=1st|year=1997|page=255|isbn=978-0879304751}}</ref> The song was eventually [[cover version|covered]] by more than 800 artists.
There were three albums released by the duo on [[Hickory Records]], only one being released before they split up. The first was ''Rusty and Doug Sing Louisiana Man'' (LPM 103) in 1961. ''Kershaw (Genus Cambarus)'' (LPS 163) was released in 1972 and was a double LP. ''Louisiana Man'' (HR 4506) was the final Hickory album, released in 1974. By 1964, the brothers had elected to go their separate ways. It took another three years before Kershaw signed a songwriters' contract with BMI, in 1967.
In June 1969, Kershaw made his first network television appearance on the debut of the ''[[The Johnny Cash Show (TV series)|Johnny Cash Show]]''.<ref name="LouisianaRocks"/> He capped the year with a week-long engagement at the New York City's [[Fillmore East]] as opening act for [[Eric Clapton]]'s [[Derek and the Dominos]]. While it seemed to many rock and pop fans that Kershaw had appeared out of nowhere, he had already sold more than 18 million copies of the records he had made in the early '60s with his brother, Rusty. "Louisiana Man" had been a Top 10 country hit in 1961 and its follow-up, "Diggy Liggy Lo", had done almost as well. His performance in front of a national audience led to [[Warner Bros. Records]] signing him to a long-term contract.<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard De La Font Agency, Inc: Doug Kershaw|url=http://delafont.com/music_acts/E/doug-kershaw.htm|publisher=Delafont.com|accessdate=2014-08-11}}</ref> In July 1969, he performed at the Newport folk festival with peers Joni Mitchell, Arlo Guthrie, Ramblin Jack Elliott, Big Mama Thornton, and Mimi Fariña, among others. Newcomers that year were Don McLean, James Taylor, and Jerry Jeff Walker. In November 1969, "Louisiana Man" was broadcast back to earth by the crew of the [[Apollo 12]] moon mission.<ref>{{cite news|title=Born on the Bayou: Exploring Louisiana in 18 Songs|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/born-on-the-bayou-exploring-louisiana-in-18-songs-20120611|accessdate=21 August 2017|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=11 June 2012}}</ref> Beyond the southern venues, Kershaw became widely known in mainstream America as he played at major urban concert halls.
In 1970, Kershaw contributed a violin part to Arlo Guthrie's [[Single (music)|record single]] Alice's Rock and Roll Restaurant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Arlo-Guthrie-Alices-Rock-And-Roll-Restaurant-Ring-Around-A-Rosy-Rag/release/2544222 |title=Arlo Guthrie - Alice's Rock And Roll Restaurant / Ring-Around-A-Rosy Rag (Vinyl) |publisher=[[Discogs]] |date= |accessdate=2015-10-17}}</ref>
In 1971, Kershaw had a musical cameo in the [[Western (genre)|Western film]] ''[[Zachariah (1971 film)|Zachariah]]'', starring [[Don Johnson]] and [[John Rubinstein]].<ref name=NYT>{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9D05E3DE163BE53BBC4D51DFB766838A669EDE|title=Zachariah (1970) Screen: 'Zachariah,' an Odd Western|authorlink=Roger Greenspun|author=Greenspun, Roger|date=January 25, 1971}}</ref>
In 1972, Kershaw played electric fiddle in Grand Funk's "Flight of the Phoenix" off their LP Phoenix. Capitol SMAS 11099<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Grand-Funk-Phoenix/release/1441635 |title=Grand Funk* - Phoenix (Vinyl, LP, Album) |publisher=[[Discogs]] |date= |accessdate=2015-10-17}}</ref>
== Later life ==
Despite the success of his solo career, Kershaw was plagued by depression and [[sadness|sorrow]]. His father had committed suicide when he was only seven.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tucker|first1=Tanya|title=100 Ways to Beat the Blues: An Uplifting Book for Anyone Who's Down|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781439106020|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6REhl5DWDwwC&pg=PA61&lpg=PA61&dq=%22Doug+Kershaw%22+%2B+suicide&source=bl&ots=B6SCcDBHzH&sig=mfOcgzoV-x1mWw_Sgu8jsnAqLJM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiurNDwqOnVAhXJLSYKHSAUA3YQ6AEIVTAG#v=onepage&q=%22Doug%20Kershaw%22%20%2B%20suicide&f=false|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> Marrying his wife, Pam, at the [[Reliant Astrodome|Houston Astrodome]] on June 21, 1975, Kershaw began raising his own family that included five sons – Douglas, Victor, Zachary, Tyler, and Elijah; and two grandsons and a granddaughter. His son, Tyler, plays drums in his band as well as manages his shows.<ref>{{cite news|title=Doug Kershaw and Steve Riley|url=http://fqfi.org/frenchquarter/artists/detail/674/Doug-Kershaw-and-Steve-Riley|accessdate=21 August 2017|publisher=French Quarter}}</ref>
Kershaw rebounded with his biggest selling hit, "Hello Woman", which reached the country music Top 40. By 1984, Kershaw's battle with [[drug abuse|drug]] and [[alcohol abuse]] came to a close and his previously erratic behavior changed for the better.<ref name="CMT"/>
In 1988, he recorded a duet, "Cajun Baby", with [[Hank Williams, Jr.]],<ref name="LouisianaRocks"/> that became a Top 50 country hit. Kershaw released a French-language album, ''Two Step Fever'', in 1999, and Michael Doucet of Beausoleil is featured on the duet "Fievre De Deux Etapes". ''Hot Diggity Doug'' was released in mid-2000 and ''Still Cajun After All These Years'' followed in early 2001. His brother Rusty died on October 23, 2001.<ref name="cmt-rusty">{{cite web|last=Morris|first=Edward|title=CMT: Rusty Kershaw, of Rusty & Doug, Dead at 63|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1450284/rusty-kershaw-of-rusty-doug-dead-at-63.jhtml|publisher=Cmt.com|date=October 23, 2001|accessdate=2014-08-11}}</ref>
Kershaw formerly owned and operated The Bayou House, a restaurant in Lucerne, Colorado, but parted ways with his partners in 2007 due to his displeasure with management and ambiance.<ref name="greeley">{{cite web|first=Kyle|last=Haas|url=http://www.greeleytribune.com/article/20080528/BUSINESS/642059053|title=Bayou House closes its doors|publisher=Greeley Tribune|date=May 28, 2008|accessdate=2010-01-27}}</ref>
In 2009, Doug was inducted into The [[Louisiana Music Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite news|title=D.L. Mendard to be Inducted Into LA Musical Hall of Fame|url=http://archive.vermiliontoday.com/dl-menard-be-inducted-la-musical-hall-fame|accessdate=21 August 2017|publisher=Vermilion Today|date=7 October 2009}}</ref>
Doug's third cousin is country music star [[Sammy Kershaw]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199920839|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&pg=PT794&dq=%22Doug+Kershaw%22+%2B+%22Sammy+Kershaw%22+cousin&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwikjKnyqenVAhWFLSYKHQKnBaEQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=%22Doug%20Kershaw%22%20%2B%20%22Sammy%20Kershaw%22%20cousin&f=false|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref>

{{About|the Italian title}} {{Infobox official post |post = Duce |body = Fascism
''Duce del Fascismo'' |insignia = Flag of Prime Minister of Italy (1927-1943).svg |insigniasize = 140px |insigniacaption = '''[[List of Italian flags|Standard of the Duce]]''' |image = Mussolini biografia.jpg |imagesize = 150px |imagecaption = '''[[Benito Mussolini]]''' |style = [[Excellency|His Excellency]] |residence = [[Palazzo Chigi]]
{{small|(1925–1929)}}
[[Palazzo Venezia]]
{{small|(1929–1943)}}
[[Villa Torlonia (Rome)|Villa Torlonia]]
{{small|(1925–1943)}} |appointer = [[Grand Council of Fascism]] |appointer_qualified = |precursor = Himself {{small|(as [[Prime Minister of Italy|Prime Minister]])}} |formation = 24 December 1925 |first = [[Benito Mussolini]] |last = Benito Mussolini |abolished = 25 July 1943 |succession = [[Marshal of Italy|Marshal]] [[Pietro Badoglio, 1st Duke of Addis Abeba|The 1st Duke of Addis Abeba]] {{small|(as Prime Minister)}}
Himself {{small|(as Duce of the [[Italian Social Republic|RSI]], as claimed by the RSI)}} |salary = }} '''''Duce''''' ({{IPA-it|ˈduːtʃe}}, "leader") is an [[Italian language|Italian]] title, derived from the [[Latin language|Latin]] word ''[[dux]]'', and [[cognate]] with ''[[duke]]''. [[National Fascist Party]] leader [[Benito Mussolini]] was identified by Fascists as ''Il Duce'' ("The [[Supreme leader|Leader]]") of the movement. In 1925 it became a reference to the [[dictator]]ial position of ''Sua Eccellenza Benito Mussolini, Capo del Governo, Duce del Fascismo e Fondatore dell'Impero'' ("''His Excellency Benito Mussolini, Head of Government, Leader of Fascism and Founder of the Empire''").[[commons:Image:Mussoliniposter.jpg|Image Description: Propaganda poster of Benito Mussolini, with caption "His Excellency Benito Mussolini, Head of Government, Leader of Fascism, and Founder of the Empire ...".]] Mussolini held this title together with that of [[President of the Council of Ministers (Italy)|President of the Council of Ministers]]: this was the constitutional position which entitled him to rule Italy on behalf of the [[King of Italy]]. ''Founder of the Empire'' was added for the exclusive use by Mussolini in recognition of his founding of an official legal entity of the [[Italian Empire]] on behalf of the King in 1936 following Italy's victory in the [[Second Italo-Ethiopian War]]. The position was held by Mussolini until 1943, when he was [[Fall of the Fascist regime in Italy|removed from office by the King]] and the position of "Duce" was dismantled, while [[Marshal of Italy|Marshal]] [[Pietro Badoglio, 1st Duke of Addis Abeba|The 1st Duke of Addis Abeba]] was appointed ''Presidente del Consiglio''. This position was the model which other [[Fascism|fascist]] leaders adopted, such as the position of ''[[Führer]]'' by [[Adolf Hitler]]. In September 1943, Mussolini styled himself as the "Duce of the [[Italian Social Republic]]" ({{lang-it|Duce della Repubblica Sociale Italiana}}), and held the position until the [[Spring 1945 offensive in Italy|collapse]] of the Italian Social Republic and [[Death of Benito Mussolini|his death]] in April 1945.Quartermaine, L. (2000). [https://books.google.com/books?id=Vwx6hN8zyIsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22italian+social+republic%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5iLjT7L0Ic7ItAa_qL3FBg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22italian%20social%20republic%22&f=false Mussolini's Last Republic: Propaganda and Politics in the Italian Social Republic]. p. 21 ==History of the term== The title was used outside its traditional noble sense in some of the publications praising [[Garibaldi]] during the [[Unification of Italy]] in 1860, though not taken up officially by Garibaldi himself.Lucy Riall, "Garibaldi, Invention of a Hero", London, 2007, Ch. 9 'Duce Supremo' ("Supreme Leader") was more formally used by [[Victor Emmanuel III of Italy|Victor Emmanuel III]] in 1915, during World War I, referring to his role as the commander in chief of the armed forces. The term was also used by [[Gabriele d'Annunzio]] as [[dictator]] of the self-proclaimed [[Italian Regency of Carnaro]] in 1920, and most significantly by the [[Italian Fascism|Fascist]] dictator [[Benito Mussolini]]. The painting 'Il Duce' by [[Gerardo Dottori]] represents Mussolini. Because the title 'Il Duce' has become associated with [[Fascism]], it is no longer in common use other than in reference to him. Because of modern anti-fascist sentiment, Italian speakers in general now use other words for leader, mainly including the English loanword. However, the term ''duce'' survives as an [[antonomasia]] for Benito Mussolini. ==Succession== Mussolini intended that the [[Grand Council of Fascism]] would choose a successor from a list of three men chosen by him, and submit the name for approval by the king. As of 1940 he may have been preparing his son-in-law [[Galeazzo Ciano]] for the role.{{cite book | url=https://archive.org/stream/in.ernet.dli.2015.149663/2015.149663.Inside-Europe#page/n277/mode/2up | title=Inside Europe | publisher=Harper & Brothers | author=Gunther, John | authorlink=John Gunther | location=New York | year=1940 | pages=255,257-258}} ==List== ===Duce of Italian Fascism=== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; border:1px #AAAAFF solid" |- !width=85px colspan="2" |Portrait !width=200px|Name
(Born–Died) !width=200px colspan=2|Term of office !width=200px|Party |- | style="background: {{National Fascist Party/meta/color}};"| |[[File:Mussolini biografia.jpg|70px]] |[[Benito Mussolini]]
(1883–1945) |24 December 1925 |25 July 1943 |[[National Fascist Party]] |} ===Duce of the Italian Social Republic=== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; border:1px #AAAAFF solid" |- !width=85px colspan="2" |Portrait !width=200px|Name
(Born–Died) !width=200px colspan=2|Term of office !width=200px|Party |- | style="background: {{Republican Fascist Party/meta/color}};"| |[[File:Mussolini biografia.jpg|70px]] |[[Benito Mussolini]]
(1883–1945) |23 September 1943 |25 April 1945 |[[Republican Fascist Party]] |} ==See also== * [[Caudillo]] * [[Conducător]] * [[Doge]] * [[Führer]] * [[Poglavnik]] * [[Roman dictator]] * [[Tenno]] * [[Strongman (politics)]] * [[Supreme Leader (disambiguation)]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Wiktionary-inline}} {{Fascism}} {{Prime ministers of Italy}} [[Category:Benito Mussolini|*]] [[Category:Italian Fascism]] [[Category:Italian Social Republic]] [[Category:Positions of authority]] [[Category:Titles of national or ethnic leadership]]

revision.text:
{{For|the Ba'al Shem of Chelm|Elijah Ba'al Shem of Chelm}} '''Elijah ben Moses Ashkenazi Loans''' (1555 – July 1636) was a German [[rabbi]] and [[Kabbalist]]. He was born in [[Frankfurt-am-Main]]. He belonged to the Rashi family, and on his mother's side was the grandson of [[Johanan Luria]], and on his father's of [[Josel of Rosheim]]. After having studied in his native city under the direction of [[Jacob Ginzburg]] and [[Akiba Frankfort]], Loans went to [[Cracow]], where he attended the lectures of [[Menahem Mendel]]. While there he prepared for publication the "''Darke Mosheh''" of [[Moses Isserles]]. At the beginning of the seventeenth century Loans was called to the rabbinate of [[Fulda]], which he left in 1612, occupying successively the rabbinates of [[Hanau]], [[Friedberg, Hesse|Friedberg]] (1620), and Worms (1630), in which last-named city he remained until his death. Loans was a diligent student of Kabbalah, and for this reason was surnamed "Ba'al Shem." He was also accomplished in music and [[calligraphy]], and various legends circulated regarding his personality. He was the author of the following works: ''Rinnat Dodim'' ([[Basel]], 1600), a commentary on [[Canticles]]; ''Miklol Yofi'' (Amsterdam, 1695), a commentary on [[Ecclesiastes]]; ''Wikkuaḥ Yayin 'im ha-Mayim'' (Amsterdam, 1757), a poem with a commentary; ''Ma'agle Ẓedeḳ'' (Neubauer, "''Catalogue of the Hebrew MSS. in the Bodleian Library''" No. 1832), a commentary on Baḥya's "''Ḥobot ha-Lebabot''"; ''Ẓofnat Pa'aneaḥ'' (Neubauer, "''Catalogue of the Hebrew MSS. in the Bodleian Library''" No. 1830), a commentary on the "''Tiḳḳune Zohar''"; a commentary on ''Genesis Rabbah'' (Neubauer, "''Catalogue of the Hebrew MSS. in the Bodleian Library''" No. 149); and ''Adderet Eliyahu'' (Neubauer, "''Catalogue of the Hebrew MSS. in the Bodleian Library''" No. 1829), a commentary on the ''[[Zohar]]''. Loans also edited the "'''Ammude Shelomoh''" of [[Solomon Luria]] on the "''[[Moses ben Jacob of Coucy#Works|Semag]]''" (Basel, 1599), and the "''Sha'are Dura''" of [[Isaac ben Meïr of Dueren]], to which he wrote a preface (Neubauer, "''Catalogue of the Hebrew MSS. in the Bodleian Library''" No. 1600).{{Jewish Encyclopedia|url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=484&letter=L&search=elijah%20loans|title=Loans, Elijah ben Moses Ashkenazi|author=K. I. Br.|accessdate=Jan 21, 2015}}
'''Jewish Encyclopedia bibliography:''' * [[Moses Mannheimer]], ''Die Juden in Worms'', p. 61, Frankfurt-am-Main, 1842 * [[L. Lewysohn]], ''Nafshot Ẓaddiḳim'', p. 59, ib. 1855 * [[Eliakim Carmoly|Carmoly]], in ''{{abbr|Jost's Annalen|Jost's Israelitische Annalen}}'', i. 94 * [[Moritz Steinschneider|Steinschneider]], ''{{abbr|Cat. Bodl.|Catalogue of the Hebrew Books in the Bodleian Library}}'' col. 942 * [[Leopold Zunz|Zunz]], ''{{abbr|Z. G.|Zur Geschichte und Literatur}}'' p. 402 * Michael, ''Or ha-Ḥayyim'', No. 401. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Loans, Elijah}} [[Category:1555 births]] [[Category:1636 deaths]] [[Category:16th-century rabbis]] [[Category:17th-century rabbis]] [[Category:16th-century German people]] [[Category:17th-century German people]] [[Category:Baal Shem]] [[Category:German rabbis]] [[Category:Kabbalists]] [[Category:People from Frankfurt]]

{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{BLP sources|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox chef <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox chef/doc]] --> | image = OSFC 2009 2 Tilson.JPG | name = Fergus Henderson | caption = Fergus Henderson at the [[Oxford Symposium on Food and Cookery]], September 2009 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1963|07|31}} | birth_place = London, England<ref>https://chefspencil.com/chefs/fergus-henderson/</ref> | death_date = | death_place = | style = [[British cuisine]] | education = | restaurants = [[St John (restaurant)|St John]] | television = }}
'''Fergus Henderson''', MBE (born 31 July 1963)<ref>{{cite news | title = Birthdays | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | pages = 33
| date = 31 July 2014 | accessdate = 31 July 2014}}</ref> is an English [[chef]] who founded the restaurant [[St John (restaurant)|St John]] on St John Street in London. He is often noted for his use of [[offal]] and other neglected cuts of meat as a consequence of his philosophy of [[The Whole Beast: Nose to Tail Eating|nose to tail eating]]. Following in the footsteps of his parents, Brian and Elizabeth Henderson, he trained as an architect at the [[Architectural Association]] in London. Most of his dishes are derived from traditional [[British cuisine]] and the wines are all French.
Chefs [[Anthony Bourdain]] and [[Mario Batali]] have both praised Henderson for his dishes, which optimise [[British food]] while making full use of the whole animal. [[A. A. Gill]] famously retracted his initial hostility to St John in the ''[[Sunday Times]]''.<ref>{{cite news|author1=John Heilpern|title=Out to Lunch with Fergus Henderson|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2013/10/fergus-henderson-interview|work=Vanity Fair|date=October 2010}}</ref>
Fergus is married to fellow chef [[Margot Henderson]]; the couple have three children; Francis, Owen and Hector.
== Career == Henderson had no formal training in cooking, and has never worked under any other chef. In 1992 Henderson and his wife, Margot, opened the French House Dining Room at Soho's [[The French House, Soho|French House]] pub before he left to open the [[St. John (restaurant)|St. John restaurant]] in 1994.<ref name=GuardAug12>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/aug/19/margot-henderson-rochelle-canteen-interview|title=Margot Henderson: British food's best-kept secret|author=[[Rachel Cooke]]|date=19 August 2012|work=The Guardian|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref> The menu at St. John changes daily, but almost always includes roast bone marrow and parsley salad. It was awarded a [[Michelin star]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.michelin.co.uk/michelinuk/en/more/news-home/news/20080225133153/24305.html|title=New Michelin Guide Great Britain & Ireland 2009 |accessdate=18 January 2009}}</ref>
In 2003 he opened St John Bread and Wine in [[Spitalfields]], London. A second St John restaurant located within the hotel in Chinatown was awarded a [[Michelin star]] in 2009. This venue is no longer open.
== ''Nose to Tail'' Books == In 1999 Henderson published ''[[Nose to Tail Eating: A Kind of British Cooking]]'' in which he provides recipes incorporating [[Pig's trotters|trotters]], [[tripe]], [[kidney]]s, [[chitterlings]] and other animal parts.<ref name=n2t>{{cite book |author= Henderson, Fergus |title=Nose to Tail Eating: A Kind of British Cooking |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |date=September 2004 |isbn=0-7475-7257-7}}</ref> The book explains the philosophy behind his cooking explaining that "it seems common sense and even polite to the animal to use all of it. Rather than being testosterone-fuelled blood-lust, it actually seems to be a gentle approach to meat eating."<ref>Douglas, Ian, ''The Daily Telegraph'' (25 October 2004). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/3315464/Swine-of-the-times.html Swine of the Times]</ref> In 2007, he published a sequel, ''Beyond Nose To Tail'', and in 2012 ''The Complete Nose to Tail: A Kind of British Cooking''.
== Hotel == Henderson opened a hotel in spring 2011 that was described by his business partner Trevor Gulliver as being 'in the St John vernacular'.<ref>Kuhn, Kerstin, caterersearch.com (9 October 2009)[http://www.caterersearch.com/Articles/2009/10/12/330334/St-John-team-to-launch-hotel-in-Londons-West-End.htm St John Team to Launch Hotel in London's West End]</ref> It was located in [[London's Chinatown]] district near [[Leicester Square]] 1 Leicester Street. However, the hotel went into administration in October 2012, and was sold and subsequently closed.
==Diagnosis with Parkinson's disease and recognition== Henderson's stoic approach to [[Parkinson's Disease]],<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2006/feb/26/foodanddrink.features6</ref> with which he was diagnosed in 1998, increased the regard in which he was held and he was awarded an [[MBE]] in 2005. The same year he underwent innovative [[Deep Brain Stimulation]] which vastly improved his mobility.<ref name=GuardAug12/>
==Bibliography== *1999 – ''[[Nose to Tail Eating: A Kind of British Cooking]]'' ([[Bloomsbury Publishing]]) {{ISBN|9780747572572}} *2007 – ''Beyond Nose to Tail: A Kind of British Cooking: Part II'' (Bloomsbury Publishing) {{ISBN|9780747589143}} *2012 – ''The Complete Nose to Tail: A Kind of British Cooking'' (Bloomsbury Publishing) {{ISBN|9781408809167}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.stjohnrestaurant.co.uk St John restaurant] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060613054806/http://www.schmick.tv/portfolio_detail.asp?id=15&item_id=47 'On Authenticity', film by Christian Banfield]
{{Authority control}} {{English cuisine}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Florence Ndagire | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | residence = [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]] | birth_name = Florence Ndagire | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1984}} | birth_place = [[Uganda]] | nationality = Ugandan | alma_mater =[[Makerere University]]
{{small|([[Bachelor of Laws]])}}
[[Law Development Centre]]
{{small|([[Diploma in Legal Practice]])}}
[[University of Leeds]]
{{small|([[Master of Laws]])}} | occupation = Lawyer | years_active = 2007 - present | home_town = [[Kampala]] | spouse = {{small|('''John Mary Nsimbi''')}} | title = Intern, [[United Nations special rapporteur|UN Special Rapporteur on Disability Rights]] | religion = }} '''Florence Ndagire''' is a female [[Uganda]]n lawyer, who works as a legal researcher and human rights lawyer at the [[United Nations]] (UN) based in [[Geneva, Switzerland]]. Ndagire, who is totally [[Visual impairment|blind]], also serves as the chairperson of the UN Women Regional Group, for [[Eastern Africa| Eastern]] and [[Southern Africa]], comprising twelve countries.{{cite web| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/Magazines/Full-Woman/A-blind-lawyer-defending-human-rights/689842-4045190-12pq9ve/index.html |title=A blind lawyer defending human rights |accessdate=12 November 2017 | date=6 August 2017 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | first=Amos | last=Ngwomoya | location=Kampala}} She is the first visually impaired person, male or female to qualify and receive licensure as a lawyer in Uganda.{{cite web|url=http://the-v.net/home/newslanding/news/did-you-know-florence-ndagire-is-the-first-visually-impaired-lawyer-in-uganda | title=Did You Know? Florence Ndagire is the First Visually Impaired Lawyer in Uganda |publisher=The-V-Net.com (TVNC) | accessdate=12 November 2017| date=11 September 2015 |author=TVNC}} ==Background and education== She was born in [[Nkokonjeru]], [[Buikwe District]] in 1984, to Joyce Nabinaka and Francis Kayizi. She was born prematurely at about six months gestation and kept in an incubator at the hospital. When her parents took her home from the hospital, they realized that their new-born was blind.{{cite web| date=24 September 2012| last=Banura | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/artsculture/Reviews/Florence-Ndagire--the-blind-lawyer/691232-1515138-9i4ceqz/index.html | first=Brenda | title=Florence Ndagire, the blind lawyer |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | accessdate=12 November 2017 |location=Kampala}} She attended Bishop Wills Primary School in [[Iganga District]]. After secondary school, she was admitted to [[Makerere University]] in [[Kampala]], to study law. While at Makerere, she was elected to the Guild Representative Council (GRC) to represent students in the Faculty of Law. After obtaining her [[Bachelor of Laws]], from Makerere, she obtained a [[Diploma in Legal Practice]] from the [[Law Development Centre]] (LDC), also in Kampala. Later she received a [[Master of Laws]] from the [[University of Leeds]] in the United Kingdom. In an interview in 2012, Ndagire credits the late [[Francis Ayume]] (1940 to 2004), with inspiring her to study law. She used to listen to Ayume on radio and television, when she was growing up, and Ayume was still alive. ==Career== Following graduation from the Law Development Centre, and her admission to the Uganda Bar in 2009, she first worked as a Legal Assistant at the law firm ''Mukisa & Mukisa Company Advocates'', working there from July 2009 until July 2010. She was then hired by the Uganda Society for Disabled Children, an [[non-profit]] organisation, working there as a Policy Lobbying and Advocacy Officer from October 2009 until October 2011. Then from March 2012 until July 2013, she was employed as a Fundraising & Advocacy Officer at the Uganda National Association of the Blind.{{cite web| url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/florence-ndagire-4619ba47/ |title=Florence Ndagire: Intern at UN Special Rapporteur on the Rights of persons with Disabilities, UN Special Rapporteur on Disability Rights| date=12 November 2017 |accessdate=12 November 2017 |publisher=[[Linkedin.com]] | author=Florence Ndagire}} In August 2013 until December 2014 she worked as a Human Rights and Fundraising Officer for the [[non-profit]] organisation [https://www.lightfortheworld.nl/welcome/ Light of the World], based in the [[Netherlands]], with offices in Uganda. She then worked for [https://www.add.org.uk/ ADD International], a non-profit based in the [[United Kingdom]]. She worked at their Kampala office, as a senior program officer from February 2015 until October 2016. Beginning in October 2016, she is employed by the [[United Nations]] (UN), as the UN Special Rapporteur on Disability Rights, based in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]. Her reports are reviewed by the Human Rights Council. ==Other considerations== Florence Ndagire is married to John Mary Nsimbi, a Ugandan and together are the parents of one son. Nsimbi works in Uganda, while Ndagire's work station is in Switzeland. He often flies to Europe to check on his wife ==See also== * [[Anna Ebaju Adeke]] * [[Rachel Mayanja]] * [[UN Special Rapporteur]] * [[First women lawyers around the world]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://beijing20.unwomen.org/en/news-and-events/stories/2014/12/woa-uganda-florence-ndagire Fighting for justice, for all - Uganda's Florencce Ndagire] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ndagire, Florence}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:Ganda people]] [[Category:Ugandan lawyers]] [[Category:Ugandan women lawyers]] [[Category:Human rights lawyers]] [[Category:Makerere University alumni]] [[Category:Law Development Centre alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Leeds]] [[Category:People from Buikwe District]] [[Category:People from Central Region, Uganda]] [[Category:Blind people]] [[Category:Blind lawyers]] [[Category:Blind people from Uganda]] [[Category:Ugandan people with disabilities]]

revision.text:
{{citation style|date=January 2018}}
'''Galina Shoidagbaeva''' (born 1953) is a [[Buryatia|Buryat]] Soviet and Russian opera soprano (soprano), a teacher. [[People's Artist of the USSR]] (1990).
Galina Shojdagbaeva was born on July 5, 1953 in the village of Sosnovo-Ozerskoe ([[Yeravninsky District]], [[Republic of Buryatia]]).
After graduating from high school, Shoydagbaeva entered the music school. Tchaikovsky in the class of People's Artist of the RSFSR N. Petrova. In 1980 she graduated from the [[Saint Petersburg Conservatory|Leningrad Rimsky-Korsakov Conservatory]] in the class of T. Novichenko.
Since 1980 - soloist of the Buryat Opera and Ballet Theater. Performs with solo concerts.
Since 1988 - a teacher at the Ulan-Ude Music College named after P. Tchaikovsky.
Galina Shoydgbaeva is a professor at the East Siberian State Academy of Culture and Arts, where in 1993 the vocal department was opened. She heads the chair of solo singing from the day of its foundation.
== Opera ==
*"Aida" by D. Verdi - Aida *Othello by D. Verdi - Desdemona *"Troubadour" by D. Verdi - Leonora *"Cio-Cio-San" J. Puccini - Madame Butterfly *"Tosca" by G. Puccini - Tosca *Turandot by J. Puccini - Turandot *"Prince Igor" P. Borodin - Yaroslavna *Iolanta by P. Tchaikovsky - Iolanthe *"The Queen of Spades" by P. Tchaikovsky - Lisa *"Carmen" by Jean Bise - Mikaela *"Enkh-Bulat bator" M. Frolova - Arjun-Goohon *"Geser" A. Andreeva - Urmai-Gokhon khatan.
== External links == * [http://www.kino-teatr.ru/teatr/acter/w/ros/392386/bio/ ШОЙДАГБАЕВА ГАЛИНА БАДМАЖАПОВНА] * [http://selorodnoe.ru/vid/show/id3632038/ Шойдагбаева Галина Бадмажаповна]
{{authority control}}

{{Infobox scholar | image = I C Filitti MI oct95.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = Filitti, ca. 1913 | name = Ioan Constantin Filitti | fullname = | other_names = Ion C. Filitti, Jean C. Filitti, F.
