{{Other people|Peter Sutcliffe}} {{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox serial killer | name= Peter Sutcliffe | image = | caption= | birth_name = Peter William Sutcliffe | alias = The Yorkshire Ripper, Peter William Coonan | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1946|6|2}} | birth_place = [[Bingley]], [[West Riding of Yorkshire]], England | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Large goods vehicle|HGV driver]] | spouse = [[Sonia Sutcliffe]] | cause = | penalty = [[Life imprisonment]] ([[whole life order]]) | victims = 13 | beginyear = 1975 | endyear = 1980 | country = United Kingdom | apprehended = 2 January 1981 | imprisoned = [[HM Prison Frankland]] }}
'''Peter William Coonan''' (born '''Peter William Sutcliffe'''; 2 June 1946) is an English [[serial killer]] who was dubbed the "'''Yorkshire Ripper'''" by the press. In 1981, Sutcliffe was convicted of murdering 13 women and attempting to murder seven others.
Sutcliffe had allegedly regularly used the services of prostitutes in [[Leeds]] and [[Bradford]]. When interviewed by authorities, he claimed that the [[voice of God]] had sent him on a mission to kill prostitutes. Sutcliffe carried out his murder spree over five years, during which time the public were especially shocked by the murders of women who were not prostitutes.<ref>''The Yorkshire Ripper: The In-Depth Study of a Mass Killer and His Methods'' {{ISBN|978-0-586-05526-7}} p. 144</ref> After his arrest for driving with false [[Vehicle registration plate|number plate]]s in January 1981, the police questioned him about the killings and he confessed to being the perpetrator.
At his trial in 1981, he pleaded not guilty to murder on grounds of [[diminished responsibility]] after a diagnosis of [[Paranoid Schizophrenia|paranoid schizophrenia]] but his defence was rejected by a majority of the jury. He is serving 20 concurrent sentences of [[life imprisonment]]. Following his conviction, Sutcliffe began using his mother's maiden name and became known as Peter William Coonan.
[[West Yorkshire Police]] were criticised for the time taken in apprehending Sutcliffe despite interviewing him nine times during the murder hunt. Because of the sensational nature of the case, the police handled an exceptional amount of information, some of it misleading (including a [[Wearside Jack|hoax recorded message]] and letters purporting to be from the "Ripper"). The 1982 Byford Report of the official inquiry (made public in 2006) confirmed the validity of the criticism.
The [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] dismissed an appeal by Sutcliffe in 2010, confirming that he would serve a [[Life imprisonment in England and Wales#Whole life order|whole life order]] and never be released from custody.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/470615/Peter-Sutcliffe-Yorkshire-Ripper-Elvis-statue-prison-for-wife|title=Peter Sutcliffe: Yorkshire Ripper makes Elvis statue for his wife|accessdate=8 July 2016|date=17 October 2015}}</ref> He was transferred from prison to a [[Broadmoor Hospital|high-security psychiatric hospital]] in March 1984. In August 2016, it was ruled that Sutcliffe was mentally fit to be returned to prison, and was transferred that month to [[HM Prison Frankland]] in Durham.
==Early life== Sutcliffe was born in [[Bingley]] in the [[West Riding of Yorkshire]] to a [[working-class]] family. He was given a Catholic upbringing by his parents,<ref>{{cite book|last=Yallop|first=David|title=Deliver us from Evil|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H7_QBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT210|year=2014|publisher=Constable & Robinson Ltd|location=London|isbn=978-1-47211-658-1}}</ref> John William Sutcliffe and his wife Kathleen Frances (née Coonan).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/sutcliffe/mask_1.html|title=A Killer's Mask|work=trutv.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090321003633/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/sutcliffe/mask_1.html|archivedate=21 March 2009|accessdate=29 October 2015}}</ref> Reportedly a loner, he left school aged fifteen and had a series of menial jobs, including two stints as a [[gravedigger]] in the 1960s.<ref name="who is Peter Sutcliffe">{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Stephen|title=Who is the Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe? History of notorious killer who brutally murdered 13 women|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/who-yorkshire-ripper-peter-sutcliffe-8616762|accessdate=6 January 2018|work=The Mirror|publisher=MGN Ltd|date=12 August 2016}}</ref> Between November 1971 and April 1973, Sutcliffe worked at the [[Baird Television Ltd.|Baird Television]] factory on a packaging line. He left this position when he was asked to go on the road as a salesman.<ref>''The Yorkshire Ripper: The In-Depth Study of a Mass Killer and His Methods'' {{ISBN|978-0-586-05526-7}} p. 63</ref>
After leaving Baird Television, he worked nightshifts at the Britannia Works of Anderton International from April 1973. In February 1975, he took [[Voluntary Redundancy|redundancy]] and used half of the £400 pay-off to train as a [[Large Goods Vehicle|heavy goods vehicle (HGV)]] driver.<ref>{{cite book|first=Gordon |last=Burn |authorlink=Gordon Burn |year=1993 |title=Somebody's Husband, Somebody's Son: The Story of Peter Sutcliffe |publisher=Mandarin |isbn=978-0-7493-1331-9 |page=142}}</ref> On 5 March 1976, he was dismissed for the theft of used tyres. He was unemployed until October 1976, when he found a job as an HGV driver for T.& W.H. Clark (Holdings) Ltd. on the Canal Road [[Industrial Estate]] in [[Bradford]].<ref>''The Yorkshire Ripper: The In-Depth Study of a Mass Killer and His Methods'' {{ISBN|978-0586-05526-7}} p. 71</ref>
Sutcliffe, by some reports, used prostitutes as a young man, and it has been speculated that he had a bad experience during which he was conned out of money.<ref>[http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/famous_criminal/54/biography/1/Peter_Sutcliffe_The_Yorkshire_Ripper.htm "Peter Sutcliffe: The Yorkshire Ripper – Famous Criminal",] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080620054640/http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/famous_criminal/54/biography/1/Peter_Sutcliffe_The_Yorkshire_Ripper.htm |date=20 June 2008 }} ''Crime And Investigation Network''</ref><ref name="Execulink.com website"/>{{Unreliable source?|date=June 2018}} Other analyses of his actions have not found evidence that he actually sought their services although he clearly expressed unusual behaviour{{clarify|reason=Expressed? + What behaviour?|date=June 2018}} before the killings.<ref name=grisly/>
He met [[Sonia Sutcliffe|Sonia Szurma]] on [[St Valentine's Day|14 February]] 1967; they married on 10 August 1974. She suffered several miscarriages and they were informed that she would not be able to have children. She resumed a teacher training course, during which time she had an affair with an ice-cream van driver. When she completed the course in 1977 and began teaching, she and Sutcliffe used her salary to buy a house in [[Heaton, West Yorkshire|Heaton]], [[Bradford]], which they moved into on 26 September 1977, and where they lived at the time of Sutcliffe's arrest.<ref>[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/sutcliffe/mask_1.html "Peter Sutcliffe" "A Killer's Mask"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090321003633/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/sutcliffe/mask_1.html |date=21 March 2009 }}, by Fiona Steel for Trutv.com</ref>
Through his childhood and his early adolescence, Sutcliffe showed no signs of abnormality. Later, in part related to his occupation as a gravedigger, he developed an unhealthy, macabre sense of humour. In his late adolescence, he developed a growing obsession with voyeurism and spent much time spying on prostitutes and the men seeking their services.<ref name=grisly>{{cite book|title=The Psychology of Serial Killer Investigations: The Grisly Business Unit|author1=Robert D. Keppel|author2=William J. Birnes|pages=32|publisher=Academic Press|date=2003|isbn=9780124042605}}</ref>
==Attacks and murders==
===1969=== Sutcliffe assaulted a prostitute he had met while searching for a woman who had tricked him out of money. He left his friend Trevor Birdsall's minivan and walked up St Paul's Road in Bradford until he was out of sight. When he returned, he was out of breath, as if he had been running. He told Birdsall to drive off quickly. Sutcliffe said he had followed a prostitute into a garage and hit her over the head with a stone in a sock. According to his statement, Sutcliffe said, "I got out of the car, went across the road and hit her. The force of the impact tore the toe off the sock and whatever was in it came out. I went back to the car and got in it".<ref name="Execulink.com website">{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/victim01.htm |title=Stone-in-sock attack |publisher=Execulink.com |date=29 September 1969 |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
Police visited his home the next day, as the woman he had attacked had noted Birdsall's [[vehicle registration plate]]. Sutcliffe admitted he had hit her, but claimed it was with his hand. The police told him he was "very lucky" as the woman did not want anything more to do with the incident – she was a known prostitute, and her husband was serving a jail term for assault.<ref name="Execulink.com website"/>
===1975=== Sutcliffe committed his second assault on the night of 5 July 1975 in [[Keighley]]. He attacked Anna Rogulskyj, who was walking alone, striking her unconscious with a [[ball-peen hammer]] and slashing her stomach with a knife. Disturbed by a neighbour, he left without killing her. Rogulskyj survived after extensive medical intervention but was [[Psychological trauma|psychologically traumatised]] by the attack.<ref>[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/sutcliffe/life_2.html TruTV.com] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001184952/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/sutcliffe/life_2.html |date=1 October 2012 }} Fiona Steel; retrieved 25 October 2010</ref>
Sutcliffe attacked Olive Smelt in [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]] in August. Employing the same ''[[modus operandi]]'', he struck her from behind and used a knife to slash her, this time above her buttocks. Again he was interrupted, and left his victim badly injured but alive. Like Rogulskyj, Smelt suffered emotional scars, including [[clinical depression]]. On 27 August, Sutcliffe attacked 14-year-old Tracy Browne in [[Silsden]]. He struck her from behind and hit her on the head five times while she was walking along a country lane. He ran off when he saw the lights of a passing car, leaving his victim requiring brain surgery. Sutcliffe was not convicted of the attack, but confessed to it in 1992.<ref>[[David Yallop|Yallop, David]]. ''Deliver Us From Evil''</ref><!-- ISBN# needed, originally published 1981 so cannot support the date unless from a later edition. -->
The first victim to lose her life in a Sutcliffe attack was Wilma McCann on 30 October. McCann, from [[Chapeltown, West Yorkshire|Chapeltown]] in [[Leeds]], was a mother of four. Sutcliffe struck her twice with a hammer before stabbing her 15 times in the neck, chest and abdomen. An extensive inquiry, involving 150 police officers and 11,000 interviews, failed to find the culprit. One of McCann's daughters died by suicide in December 2007, reportedly after suffering years of depression over her mother's death.<ref>Stratton, Allegra. [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/dec/27/ukcrime.uk "Daughter Of Ripper Victim Kills Herself",] ''The Guardian''. 27 December 2007</ref>
===1976=== Sutcliffe committed his next murder in Leeds in January 1976, when he stabbed 42-year-old Emily Jackson 52 times. In dire financial straits, Jackson had been using the family van to exchange sexual favours for money. Sutcliffe picked up Jackson who was soliciting outside the Gaiety pub on Roundhay Road, he then drove about half a mile to some derelict buildings on Enfield Terrace in the Manor Industrial Estate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/victim07.htm|title=THE ATTACKS AND MURDERS - EMILY JACKSON|website=www.execulink.com}}</ref> Sutcliffe hit her on the head with a hammer, and then dragged her body into a rubbish strewn yard and used a sharpened screwdriver to stab her in the neck, chest and abdomen. Sutcliffe stamped on her thigh, leaving behind an impression of his boot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/victim07.htm |title=Emily Jackson |publisher=Execulink.com |date=20 January 1976 |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
Sutcliffe attacked 20-year-old Marcella Claxton in [[Roundhay Park]], Leeds, on 9 May. Walking home from a party, she accepted an offer of a lift from Sutcliffe. When she got out of the car to urinate, Sutcliffe hit her from behind with a hammer. She was left alive and testified against Sutcliffe at his trial. At the time of this attack, Claxton had been four months pregnant, and subsequently suffered a miscarriage.<ref name="who is Peter Sutcliffe"/>
===1977=== On 5 February Sutcliffe attacked Irene Richardson, a Chapeltown prostitute, in Roundhay Park. Richardson was bludgeoned to death with a hammer. Once she was dead, he mutilated her corpse with a knife. Tyre<!-- Please retain British English spelling 'tyre' in this sentence --> tracks left near the murder scene resulted in a long list of possible suspect vehicles.<ref>''The Yorkshire Ripper'' {{ISBN|978-0586-05526-7}} p. 36</ref>
Two months later, on 23 April, Sutcliffe killed Patricia "Tina" Atkinson, a prostitute from Bradford, in her flat, where police found a bootprint on the bedclothes. Two months later on 26 June, he murdered 16-year-old Jayne MacDonald in Chapeltown. She was not a prostitute and, in the public perception, showed that all women were potential victims.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/victim11.htm |title=Jayne MacDonald |publisher=Execulink.com |date=26 June 1977 |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref> Sutcliffe seriously assaulted Maureen Long in Bradford in July. He was interrupted and left her for dead. A witness misidentified the make of his car. More than 300 police officers collected 12,500 statements and checked thousands of cars, without success. On 1 October 1977 Sutcliffe murdered Jean Jordan, a prostitute from [[Manchester]].<ref>{{cite book| last = Cross| first = Roger| title = Yorkshire Ripper| year = 1981| publisher = HarperCollins UK| isbn = 978-0-586-05526-7| page = 92 }}</ref> Her body was found 10 days later and had been moved several days after her death. In a confession, Sutcliffe said he had realised the new £5 note he had given her was traceable. After hosting a family party at his new home, he returned to the wasteland behind Manchester's [[Southern Cemetery, Manchester|Southern Cemetery]], where he had left the body, to retrieve the note. Unable to find it, he mutilated Jordan's corpse and moved it.<ref name="execulink.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/victim13.htm |title=Jean Jordan |publisher=Execulink.com |date=1 October 1977 |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
The following morning, Jordan's body was discovered by a local dairy worker, [[Bruce Jones (actor)|Bruce Jones]], who had an [[Allotment (gardening)|allotment]] on land adjoining the site where the body was found and was searching for house bricks when he made the discovery. The £5 note, hidden in a secret compartment in Jordan's handbag, was traced to branches of the [[Midland Bank]] in [[Shipley, West Yorkshire|Shipley]] and [[Bingley]]. Police analysis of bank operations allowed them to narrow their field of inquiry to 8,000 employees who could have received it in their wage packet. Over three months the police interviewed 5,000 men, including Sutcliffe. The police found that the alibi given for Sutcliffe's whereabouts was credible; he had indeed spent much of the evening of the killing at a family party. Weeks of intense investigations pertaining to the origins of the £5 note led to nothing, leaving police officers frustrated that they collected an important clue, but had been unable to trace the actual firm (or employee within the firm) to which the note had been issued.<ref name=shook>"The Yorkshire Ripper". ''Crimes That Shook Britain'': Season 4, Episode 4. (6 October 2013).</ref>
On 14 December, Sutcliffe attacked Marilyn Moore, another prostitute from Leeds. She survived and provided police with a description of her attacker.<!-- Please retain British English spelling 'tyre' in following sentence --> Tyre tracks found at the scene matched those from an earlier attack.<ref name="who is Peter Sutcliffe"/>
===1978=== The police discontinued the search for the person who received the £5 note in January 1978. Although Sutcliffe was interviewed about it, he was not investigated further (he was contacted and disregarded by the Ripper Squad on several further occasions). That month, Sutcliffe killed again. His victim was Yvonne Pearson, a 21-year-old prostitute from Bradford. He repeatedly bludgeoned her about the head with a ball-pein hammer then jumped on her chest before stuffing horse-hair into her mouth from a discarded sofa under which he hid her body near Lumb Lane.<ref>''The Yorkshire Ripper'' {{ISBN|978-0-586-05526-7}} p. 107</ref> Her body was not found until 26 March.
Ten days later, he killed Helen Rytka, an 18-year-old prostitute from [[Huddersfield]]. He struck Rytka on the head five times as she exited his vehicle, before stripping many of her clothes from her body (although her bra and polo-neck jumper were positioned above her breasts), before repeatedly stabbing her in the chest. Her body was found beneath railway arches in the timber-yard to which he had driven her three days later.<ref>''The Yorkshire Ripper'' {{ISBN|978-0-586-05526-7}} p. 112</ref>
On 16 May, Sutcliffe killed Vera Millward in an attack in the car park of [[Manchester Royal Infirmary]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/victim17.htm |title=website |publisher=Execulink.com |date=16 May 1978 |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
===1979=== On 4 April 1979, Sutcliffe killed Josephine Whitaker, a 19-year-old building society clerk whom he attacked on Saville Park Moor in Halifax as she was walking home. Despite forensic evidence, police efforts were diverted for several months following receipt of a taped message purporting to be from the murderer taunting Assistant Chief Constable [[George Oldfield (detective)|George Oldfield]], who was leading the investigation. The tape contained a man's voice saying "I'm Jack. I see you're having no luck catching me. I have the greatest respect for you, George, but Lord, you're no nearer catching me now than four years ago when I started."<ref>''The Chronicle of Crime: The infamous felons of modern history and their hideous crimes'' by Martin Fido</ref>
Based on the recorded message, police began searching for a man with a [[Wearside]] accent, which linguists narrowed down to the [[Castletown, Tyne and Wear|Castletown]] area of [[Sunderland, Tyne and Wear|Sunderland]]. The hoaxer, dubbed "[[Wearside Jack]]", sent two letters to police and ''The Daily Mirror'' in March 1978 boasting of his crimes. The letters, signed "[[Jack the Ripper]]", claimed responsibility for the murder of 26-year-old Joan Harrison in [[City of Preston, Lancashire|Preston]] in November 1975. At the time, police mistakenly believed that the Preston murder was not public knowledge. (The hoaxer case was re-opened in 2005, and DNA taken from envelopes was entered into the national database. On 20 October 2005, [[John Samuel Humble]], an unemployed alcoholic and long-time resident of the [[Ford Estate]] in Sunderland – a few miles from Castletown – was charged with attempting to pervert the course of justice for sending the hoax letters and tape. Humble, whose DNA had been taken following a drunk and disorderly offence in 2001, was remanded in custody and on 21 March 2006 was convicted and sentenced to eight years in prison.)<ref>{{cite news|last1=Herbert|first1=Ian|title=Wearside Jack: I deserve to go to jail for 'evil' Ripper hoax|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/wearside-jack-i-deserve-to-go-to-jail-for-evil-ripper-hoax-6106028.html|accessdate=11 November 2017|work=The Independent|date=21 March 2006}}</ref>
On 1 September, Sutcliffe murdered 20-year-old Barbara Leach, a [[University of Bradford|Bradford University]] student. Her body was dumped at the rear of 13 Ashgrove under a pile of bricks, close to the university and her lodgings. It was his 16th attack. The murder of a woman who was not a prostitute again alarmed the public and prompted an expensive publicity campaign emphasising the Wearside connection. Despite the false lead, Sutcliffe was interviewed on at least two other occasions in 1979. Despite matching several forensic clues and being on the list of 300 names in connection with the £5 note, he was not strongly suspected. Sutcliffe was interviewed by police nine times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/intervws.htm |title=Vera Millward |publisher=Execulink.com |date= |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
===1980=== In April 1980 Sutcliffe was arrested for drunk-driving. While awaiting trial, he killed two more women. He murdered 47-year-old Marguerite Walls on the night of 20 August, and 20-year-old Jacqueline Hill, a student at [[University of Leeds|Leeds University]], on the night of 17 November. Hill's body was found in the grounds of the Lupton Residences. He attacked three other women who survived; Dr Uphadya Bandara in Leeds on 24 September, Maureen Lea (known as Mo),<ref>{{cite news|last=Cocozza|first=Paula|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/dec/05/mo-lea-artist-yorkshire-ripper-peter-sutcliffe|title='I've turned the tables on Peter Sutcliffe': artist Mo Lea on why she finally drew her attacker|work=The Guardian|date=5 December 2017|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref> an art student attacked in the grounds of Leeds University on 25 October and 16-year-old Theresa Sykes, attacked in Huddersfield on the night of 5 November. On 25 November Trevor Birdsall, an associate of Sutcliffe, reported him to the police as a suspect but the information vanished into the paperwork already accumulated.<ref name="who is Peter Sutcliffe"/>
==Arrest and trial== [[File:Milgarth Police Station, Leeds.jpg|thumb|right|Millgarth Police Station in [[Leeds city centre]], where the Yorkshire Ripper police investigation was conducted.]]
On 2 January 1981, Sutcliffe was stopped by the police with 24-year-old prostitute Olivia Reivers in the driveway of Light Trades House in Melbourne Avenue, [[Broomhill (ward)|Broomhill]], [[Sheffield]]. A police check by probationary constable Robert Hydes revealed his car had false number plates and Sutcliffe was arrested and transferred to [[Dewsbury]] Police Station. At Dewsbury he was questioned in relation to the Yorkshire Ripper case as he matched many of the known physical characteristics. The next day police returned to the scene of the arrest and discovered a knife, hammer and rope he had discarded when he briefly slipped away from the police after telling them he was "bursting for a pee". Sutcliffe hid a second knife in the toilet cistern at the police station when he was permitted to use the toilet. The police obtained a [[search warrant]] for his home at 6 Garden Lane in Heaton, Bradford and brought his wife in for questioning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/arrest.htm |title=Arrest and confession |publisher=Execulink.com |date= |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
When Sutcliffe was stripped at the police station he was wearing an inverted V-neck sweater under his trousers. The sleeves had been pulled over his legs and the V-neck exposed his genital area. The front of the elbows were padded to protect his knees as, presumably, he knelt over his victims' corpses. The sexual implications of this outfit were considered obvious, but it was not made public until the 2003 book, ''Wicked Beyond Belief: The Hunt for the Yorkshire Ripper'', by Michael Bilton was published. After two days of intensive questioning, on the afternoon of 4 January 1981 Sutcliffe suddenly declared he was the Ripper. Over the next day, Sutcliffe calmly described his many attacks. Weeks later he claimed God had told him to murder the women. He displayed emotion only when telling of the killing of his youngest victim, Jayne MacDonald, and when questioned about the murder of Joan Harrison, which he vehemently denied committing. Harrison's murder had been linked to the Ripper killings by the "Wearside Jack" claim, and in 2011, [[DNA profiling|DNA evidence]] proved it had been committed by convicted sex offender Christopher Smith, who had died in 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=DNA helps police 'solve' 1975 Joan Harrison murder|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lancashire-12396506|accessdate=2 January 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=9 February 2011}}</ref>
Sutcliffe was charged at Dewsbury on 5 January.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/confessn.htm |title=Statement |publisher=Execulink.com |date= |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref> At his trial, he pleaded not guilty to 13 charges of murder, but guilty to [[manslaughter in English law|manslaughter]] on the grounds of [[diminished responsibility in English law|diminished responsibility]]. The basis of his defence was he claimed to be the tool of God's will. Sutcliffe claimed to have heard voices that ordered him to kill prostitutes while working as a gravedigger. He said the voices originated from a headstone of a Polish man, Bronisław Zapolski,<ref>[http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/trial04.htm "The Trial: Week Two"], Trial of Peter Sutcliffe</ref> and that the voices were that of God.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/2833589.stm "MP's Ripper prison demand",] ''BBC World News''. 9 March 2003</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20120527001131/http://www.crimeandjustice.us/forums/lofiversion/index.php?t6951.html "Yorkshire Ripper, Peter Sutcliffe's Weight-Gain Strategy in Latest Bid for Freedom",] ''New Criminologist''. 25 May 2005</ref>
He pleaded guilty to seven charges of attempted murder. The prosecution intended to accept Sutcliffe's plea after four psychiatrists diagnosed him with [[paranoid schizophrenia]] but the trial judge, Mr Justice Boreham, demanded an unusually detailed explanation of the prosecution reasoning. After a two-hour representation by the [[Attorney General for England and Wales|Attorney-General]] [[Michael Havers|Sir Michael Havers]], a 90-minute lunch break and another 40 minutes of legal discussion, the judge rejected the diminished responsibility plea and the expert testimonies of the psychiatrists, insisting that the case should be dealt with by a jury. The trial proper was set to commence on 5 May 1981.<ref>[http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/trial01.htm Execulink.com website].</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/trial03.htm |title=Trial: week 1 |publisher=Execulink.com |date= |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref>
The trial lasted two weeks and despite the efforts of his counsel [[James Chadwin|James Chadwin QC]], Sutcliffe was found guilty of murder on all counts and was sentenced to 20 concurrent sentences of [[life imprisonment]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/22/newsid_2504000/2504409.stm "1981: Yorkshire Ripper jailed for life"], BBC On This Day, 22 May</ref> The trial judge said Sutcliffe was beyond redemption, and hoped he would never leave prison. He recommended a minimum term of 30 years to be served before parole could be considered meaning Sutcliffe would have been unlikely to be freed until at least 2011. On 16 July 2010, the [[High Court]] issued Sutcliffe with a [[whole life tariff]], meaning he is unlikely ever to be released. The whole life tariff was introduced by the government in 1983, and over the next 20 years it was reported that Sutcliffe was among the small group of prisoners to have been issued with a whole life tariff. Politicians were stripped of their powers to set minimum terms for life sentence prisoners in November 2002, and the final say on how long a life sentence prisoner can serve has since rested with the High Court.
After his trial, Sutcliffe admitted two other attacks. It was decided that prosecution for these offences was "not in the public interest". [[West Yorkshire Police]] made it clear that the victims wished to remain anonymous.<ref>[http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/otherv.htm Execulink.com website]; retrieved 25 October 2010</ref>
==Criticism of West Yorkshire Police== West Yorkshire Police were criticised for being inadequately prepared for an investigation on this scale. It was one of the largest investigations by a British police force and predated the use of computers. Information on suspects was stored on handwritten index cards. Aside from difficulties in storing and accessing the paperwork (the floor of the incident room was reinforced to cope with the weight of the paper), it was difficult for officers to overcome the information overload of such a large manual system. Sutcliffe was interviewed nine times,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-34615802|title= One Girl's Life in the Ripper Years|accessdate=26 July 2017|newspaper=BBC|date=2 November 2015}}</ref> but all information the police had about the case was stored in paper form, making cross-referencing difficult, compounded by television appeals for information which generated thousands more documents. The 1982 Byford report into the investigation concluded 'The ineffectiveness of the major incident room was a serious handicap to the Ripper investigation. While it should have been the effective nerve centre of the whole police operation, the backlog of unprocessed information resulted in the failure to connect vital pieces of related information. This serious fault in the central index system allowed Peter Sutcliffe to continually slip through the net'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/byfdsamp.htm|title=BYFORD AND SAMPSON REPORTS|website=www.execulink.com}}</ref>
Assistant Chief Constable George Oldfield was criticised for being too focused on a hoax confessional tape<ref>Serial Murderers {{ISBN|1-85435-834-0}} pp. 86–87</ref> that seemed to indicate a perpetrator with a Wearside background,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jun/15/story-of-yorkshire-ripper-hoaxer-wearside-jack-to-be-made-into-movie|title=Story of Yorkshire Ripper Hoaxer 'Wearside Jack' to be Made into Movie |accessdate=26 July 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|date=15 June 2015}}</ref> and for ignoring advice from survivors of Sutcliffe's attacks, and several eminent specialists including the [[FBI]], plus dialect analysts such as Stanley Ellis and Jack Windsor Lewis,<ref>Serial Murderers {{ISBN|1-85435-834-0}} p. 88</ref> whom he had also consulted throughout the manhunt, that "Wearside Jack" was a blatant hoaxer.{{refn|group=n|George Oldfield and other senior individuals involved in the hunt for the Yorkshire Ripper had consulted senior [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] [[Special agent|Special Agent]]s [[John E. Douglas|John Douglas]] and [[Robert Ressler]] in an effort to construct a [[offender profiling|psychological profile]] of the Yorkshire Ripper in 1979. After playing the hoax tape to Ressler and Douglas, Ressler said to Oldfield: "You do realise, of course, that the man on the tape is not the killer, don't you?" Oldfield chose to ignore this observation.<ref>Whoever Fights Monsters {{ISBN|0-671-71561-5}} pp. 260–261</ref>}} The investigation used it as a point of elimination rather than a line of enquiry and allowed Sutcliffe to avoid scrutiny, as he did not fit the profile of the sender of the tape or letters. The "Wearside Jack" hoaxer was given unusual credibility when analysis of saliva on the envelopes he sent showed he had the same blood group as the Yorkshire Ripper had left at crime scenes, a type shared by only 6% of the population. The hoaxer appeared to know details of the murders which had not been released to the press, but which in fact he had acquired from his local newspaper and pub gossip. The official response to the criticisms led to the implementation of the forerunner of the [[Home Office Large Major Enquiry System]], the development of the Major Incident Computer Application (MICA), developed between West Yorkshire Police and ISIS Computer Services.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}}
In response to the police reaction to the murders, the [[Leeds Revolutionary Feminist Group]] organised a number of '[[Reclaim the Night]]' marches. The group and other feminists had criticised the police for victim-blaming, especially the suggestion that women should remain indoors at night. Eleven marches in various towns across the United Kingdom took place on the night of 12 November 1977. They made the point that women should be able to walk anywhere without restriction and that they should not be blamed for men's violence.<ref>Serial Murderers {{ISBN|1-85435-834-0}} p. 83</ref>
In 1988, the mother of Sutcliffe's last victim, Jacqueline Hill, during action for damages on behalf of her daughter's estate, argued in the High Court that the police had failed to use reasonable care in apprehending the murderer of her daughter in ''[[Hill v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire]]''. The [[Judicial functions of the House of Lords|House of Lords]] held that the [[Chief Constable]] of West Yorkshire did not owe a [[duty of care in English law|duty of care]] to the victim due to the lack of proximity and therefore failing on the second limb of the [[Caparo test|''Caparo'' test]].<ref>[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200405/ldjudgmt/jd050421/brooks-1.htm "Judgments – Brooks (FC) (Respondent) v. Commissioner of Police for the Metropolis (Appellant) and others",] ''House of Lords Publications''. 21 April 2005.</ref>
==Byford Report== The [[Inspector of Constabulary]] Sir Lawrence Byford's 1981 report of an official inquiry into the Ripper case was not released by the Home Office until 1 June 2006. The sections "Description of suspects, photofits and other assaults" and parts of the section on Sutcliffe's "immediate associates" were not disclosed by the Home Office.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/mistakes-that-left-ripper-on-the-loose-1-2372470|title= Mistakes that left Ripper on the loose|work=The Yorkshire Post|date=2 June 2006|accessdate=26 July 2017}}</ref>
Referring to the period between 1969, when Sutcliffe first came to the attention of police, and 1975, the year of the murder of Wilma McCann, the report states: "There is a curious and unexplained lull in Sutcliffe's criminal activities" and "it is my firm conclusion that between 1969 and 1980 Sutcliffe was probably responsible for many attacks on unaccompanied women, which he has not yet admitted, not only in the West Yorkshire and Manchester areas but also in other parts of the country".<ref name="Evans">{{cite news|last1=Evans|first1=Rob|last2=Campbell|first2=Duncan|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/jun/02/freedomofinformation.ukcrime|title=Ripper guilty of additional crimes, says secret report|work=The Guardian|date=2 June 2006|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref> In 1969 Sutcliffe, described in the Byford Report as an "otherwise unremarkable young man", came to the notice of police on two occasions over incidents with prostitutes.<ref name="SMH">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/ripper-may-have-attacked-more/2006/06/02/1148956547934.html|title=Ripper may have attacked more|work=Sydney Morning Herald|agency=Reuters|date=3 June 2006|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref> Later that year, in September,<ref>{{cite news|last=Norfolk|first=Andrew|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/uk/crime/article2461911.ece|title=Peter Sutcliffe, the bullied mummy’s boy who gave millions nightmares|work=The Times|location=London|date=2 March 2010|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref> he was also arrested in Bradford's [[red light district]] for being in possession of a hammer, an offensive weapon, but he was charged with "going equipped for stealing" as it was assumed he was a potential burglar.<ref name="home office">"Sir Lawrence Byford report into the police handling of the Yorkshire Ripper case", ''Home Office''</ref><ref name="SMH"/> The report said that it was clear he had on at least one occasion attacked a Bradford prostitute with a [[Club (weapon)|cosh]].<ref name="SMH"/>
Byford's report states:
{{quote|We feel it is highly improbable that the crimes in respect of which Sutcliffe has been charged and convicted are the only ones attributable to him. This feeling is reinforced by examining the details of a number of assaults on women since 1969 which, in some ways, clearly fall into the established pattern of Sutcliffe's overall modus operandi. I hasten to add that I feel sure that the senior police officers in the areas concerned are also mindful of this possibility but, in order to ensure full account is taken of all the information available, I have arranged for an effective liaison to take place.<ref name="home office"/>}}
Police identified a number of attacks which matched Sutcliffe's modus operandi and tried to question the killer, but he was never charged with other crimes.
The Byford Report's major findings were contained in a summary published by the [[Home Secretary]], [[William Whitelaw]], the first time precise details of the bungled police investigation had been disclosed. Sir Lawrence described delays in following up vital tip-offs from Trevor Birdsall, an associate of Sutcliffe since 1966. On 25 November 1980, Birdsall sent an anonymous letter to police, the text of which ran as follows:
{{quote|I have good reason to {{sic|now}} the man you are looking for in the Ripper case. This man {{sic|as|nolink=yes}} dealings with prostitutes and always had a thing about them… His name and address is Peter Sutcliffe, 6 Garden Lane, Heaton, Bradford. Works for Clarke's Transport, Shipley.<ref name="home office"/>}}
This letter was marked "Priority No 1". An index card was created on the basis of the letter and a policewoman found Sutcliffe already had three existing index cards in the records. But "for some inexplicable reason", said the Byford Report, the papers remained in a filing tray in the incident room until the murderer's arrest on 2 January the following year.<ref name="home office"/>
Birdsall visited Bradford Police Station the day after sending the letter to repeat his misgivings about Sutcliffe. He added that he was with Sutcliffe when he got out of a car to pursue a woman with whom he had had a bar room dispute in Halifax on 16 August 1975. This was the date and place of the Olive Smelt attack. A report compiled on the visit was lost, despite a "comprehensive search" which took place after Sutcliffe's arrest, according to the report.<ref name="home office"/> Byford said:
{{quote|The failure to take advantage of Birdsall's anonymous letter and his visit to the police station was yet again a stark illustration of the progressive decline in the overall efficiency of the major incident room. It resulted in Sutcliffe being at liberty for more than a month when he might conceivably have been in custody. Thankfully, there is no reason to think he committed any further murderous assaults within that period.<ref name="home office"/>}}
==Custody== ===Prison and Broadmoor Hospital=== Following his conviction and incarceration, Sutcliffe chose to use the name Coonan, his mother's maiden name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcc.org.uk/news/index.html?article=NDQ0Mg==|title=74 Adjudication|work=News & Features|publisher=Press Complaints Commission|date=29 January 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207144321/http://www.pcc.org.uk/news/index.html?article=NDQ0Mg%3D%3D|archivedate=7 December 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> He began his sentence at [[Parkhurst (HM Prison)|HMP Parkhurst]] on 22 May 1981. Despite being found sane at his trial, he was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. Attempts to send him to a secure psychiatric unit were blocked. While at Parkhurst he was seriously assaulted by James Costello, a 35-year-old career criminal with several convictions for violence. On 10 January 1983, he followed Sutcliffe into the recess of F2, the hospital wing at Parkhurst Prison and plunged a broken coffee jar twice into the left side of Sutcliffe's face, creating four wounds requiring 30 stitches.<ref name="Brannen">[http://www.execulink.com/~kbrannen/attackps.htm "Attacks on Peter Sutcliffe",] ''The Yorkshire Ripper''.</ref> In March 1984 Sutcliffe was sent to [[Broadmoor Hospital]], under Section 47 of the [[Mental Health Act 1983]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/peter-sutcliffe-yorkshire-ripper-moved-from-broadmoor-psychiatric-hospital-to-prison-a7210211.html|title=Yorkshire Ripper moved back to prison after 32 years in Broadmoor|publisher=|date=25 August 2016}}</ref>
His wife obtained a separation from him in 1982 and a divorce in April 1994. On 23 February 1996, Sutcliffe was attacked in his room in Broadmoor Hospital's Henley Ward. Paul Wilson, a convicted robber, asked to borrow a videotape before attempting to strangle him with the cable from a pair of stereo headphones. Two other convicted murderers, [[Kenneth Erskine]] and Jamie Devitt, intervened on hearing screams.<ref name="Brannen"/>
After an attack with a pen by fellow inmate Ian Kay on 10 March 1997, Sutcliffe lost the vision in his left eye, and his right eye was severely damaged.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/crime/caseclosed/yorkshireripper1.shtml|title= Crime Case Closed: Peter Sutcliffe, the Yorkshire Ripper|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070127141209/http://www.bbc.co.uk/crime/caseclosed/yorkshireripper1.shtml|archivedate=27 January 2007|work=BBC News|date=27 January 2007|accessdate=25 January 2014}}</ref> Kay admitted trying to kill Sutcliffe, and was ordered to be detained in a secure mental hospital without limit of time.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Anon|title=Deranged killer admits Yorkshire Ripper blinding|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/51090.stm|accessdate=6 January 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=27 January 1998}}</ref>
In 2003 it was reported that Sutcliffe had developed diabetes.<ref>[http://www.cravenherald.co.uk/archive/2003/08/30/Bradford+District+Archive/8010330.Ripper_Sutcliffe_has_diabetes/ "Ripper Sutcliffe has diabetes",] ''Craven Herald and Pioneer'', 30 August 2003</ref>
Sutcliffe's father died in 2004 and was cremated. On 17 January 2005 Sutcliffe was allowed to visit [[Grange-over-Sands]] where the ashes had been scattered. The decision to allow the temporary release was initiated by [[David Blunkett]] and ratified by [[Charles Clarke]] when he became Home Secretary. Sutcliffe was accompanied by four members of the hospital staff. Despite the passage of 25 years since the Ripper murders, Sutcliffe's visit was the focus of front-page tabloid headlines.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/west_yorkshire/4190525.stm "Ripper visits father's ashes site",] ''BBC News Online''. 20 January 2005</ref>
On 22 December 2007, Sutcliffe was attacked by fellow inmate Patrick Sureda, who lunged at him with a metal cutlery knife while shouting "You fucking raping, murdering bastard, I'll blind your fucking other one". Sutcliffe flung himself backwards and the blade missed his right eye, stabbing him in the cheek.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2007/dec/24/ukcrime1 "Yorkshire Ripper stabbed in face"], ''The Guardian'', 24 December 2007</ref>
On 17 February 2009, it was reported<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/lawandorder/4684906/Yorkshire-Ripper-Peter-Sutcliffe-fit-to-be-freed-from-Broadmoor.html "Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe 'fit to be freed from Broadmoor'."] ''Daily Telegraph''. 17 February 2009.</ref> that Sutcliffe was "fit to leave Broadmoor". On 23 March 2010, the [[Secretary of State for Justice]], [[Jack Straw]], was questioned by [[Julie Kirkbride]], [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MP for [[Bromsgrove]], in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] seeking reassurance for a constituent, a victim of Sutcliffe, that he would remain in prison. Straw responded that whilst the matter of Sutcliffe's release was a parole board matter, "that all the evidence that I have seen on this case, and it's a great deal, suggests to me that there are no circumstances in which this man will be released".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bradford/8583782.stm|title='No release' for Yorkshire Ripper, says Jack Straw|publisher=BBC News|date=23 March 2010|accessdate=8 July 2010}}</ref>
===Appeal=== An application by Sutcliffe for a minimum term to be set, offering the possibility of parole after that date if it is thought safe to release him, was heard by the [[High Court of Justice]] on 16 July 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/Summer-date-for-hearing-that.6279399.jp|title=Summer date for hearing that could lead to parole for Ripper|last=Casci|first=Mark|date=7 May 2010|work=[[Yorkshire Post]]|accessdate=17 May 2010}}</ref> The High Court decided that Sutcliffe will never be released.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Yorkshire-Ripper-Peter-Sutcliffe-Now-Peter-Coonan-Will-Never-Be-Released-High-Court-Rules/Article/201007315666004?f=rss |title=Yorkshire Ripper Will Never Be Released |work=Sky News Online''|date= 17 July 2010|accessdate= 25 October 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719194229/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Yorkshire-Ripper-Peter-Sutcliffe-Now-Peter-Coonan-Will-Never-Be-Released-High-Court-Rules/Article/201007315666004?f=rss|archivedate=19 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Yorkshire-Ripper-Peter-Sutcliffe-Loses-Challenge-Against-High-Court-That-He-Can-Never-Be-Released/Article/201101215894887?lpos=UK_News_Third_Home_Page_Article_Teaser_Region__4&lid=ARTICLE_15894887_Yorkshire_Ripper_Peter_Sutcliffe_Loses_Challenge_Against_High_Court_That_He_Can_Never_Be_Released|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120716182352/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Yorkshire-Ripper-Peter-Sutcliffe-Loses-Challenge-Against-High-Court-That-He-Can-Never-Be-Released/Article/201101215894887?lpos=UK_News_Third_Home_Page_Article_Teaser_Region__4&lid=ARTICLE_15894887_Yorkshire_Ripper_Peter_Sutcliffe_Loses_Challenge_Against_High_Court_That_He_Can_Never_Be_Released|dead-url=yes|archivedate=16 July 2012|title=Yorkshire Ripper To Remain Locked Up For Life|date=14 January 2011|work=Sky News|publisher=BskyB|accessdate=16 January 2011}}</ref> Mr Justice Mitting stated:
{{quote|This was a campaign of murder which terrorised the population of a large part of Yorkshire for several years. The only explanation for it, on the jury's verdict, was anger, hatred and obsession. Apart from a terrorist outrage, it is difficult to conceive of circumstances in which one man could account for so many victims.<ref>{{cite BAILII|country=ew|litigants=R v PETER COONAN (FORMERLY SUTCLIFFE)|court=EWHC|division=QB|year=2010|num=1741|para=16|date=16 July 2010}}</ref>}}
Psychological Reports describing his mental state were taken into consideration, as was the severity of his crimes.<ref name="Coleman">{{cite news|first=Clive |last=Coleman |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-10657290 |title=Sutcliffe's life term |publisher=BBC News |date=16 July 2010 |accessdate=18 June 2011}}</ref> Barring judicial decisions to the contrary, Sutcliffe will spend the rest of his life in Broadmoor Hospital. On 4 August 2010, a spokeswoman for the Judicial Communications Office confirmed that Sutcliffe had initiated an appeal against the decision.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/7926151/Yorkshire-Ripper-Peter-Sutcliffe-challenges-whole-life-ruling.html|title=Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe challenges 'whole life' ruling|newspaper=Telegraph|date=4 August 2010|accessdate=31 August 2010|location=London}}</ref>
The hearing for Sutcliffe's appeal against the ruling began on 30 November 2010 at the [[Court of Appeal of England and Wales|Court of Appeal]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/nov/30/yorkshire-ripper-peter-sutcliffe-appeal | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Caroline | last=Davies | title=Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe challenges full-life jail sentence | date=30 November 2010}}</ref> It was rejected on 14 January 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bradford-west-yorkshire-12184892|title=Yorkshire Ripper loses bid to appeal 'whole life' term|publisher=BBC News|date=14 January 2011|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> On 9 March 2011, the Court of Appeal rejected Sutcliffe's application for leave to appeal to the [[Supreme Court of the United Kingdom|Supreme Court]].<ref name="BBC392011">{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bradford-west-yorkshire-12687837 |title= Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe loses life tariff case |first= |last= |work= BBC News |accessdate=9 March 2011 |date=9 March 2011}}</ref>
In December 2015 Sutcliffe was assessed as being "no longer mentally ill".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-34971535|title=Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe 'facing Broadmoor exit'|date=1 December 2015|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=1 December 2015}}</ref> In August 2016, a medical tribunal ruled that he no longer required clinical treatment for his mental condition, and could be returned to prison. Sutcliffe is reported to have been transferred from Broadmoor to [[Frankland Prison]] in Durham in August 2016.<ref name="BBC250816">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-37183247|title=Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe moved from Broadmoor to prison|publisher=BBC News|date=25 August 2016|accessdate=25 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.examiner.co.uk/news/west-yorkshire-news/yorkshire-ripper-moved-back-prison-11796787|title=Yorkshire Ripper moved back to prison from psychiatric hospital|date=25 August 2016|work=The Huddersfield Daily Examiner|accessdate=25 August 2016}}</ref>
==Legacy== On 26 August 2016 the police investigation was the subject of [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''The Reunion''. [[Sue MacGregor]] discussed the investigation with John Domaille, who later became assistant chief constable of West Yorkshire Police; Andy Laptew, who was a junior detective who interviewed Sutcliffe; Elaine Benson, who worked in the incident room and interviewed suspects; David Zackrisson, who investigated the "Wearside Jack" tape and letters in Sunderland and [[Christa Ackroyd]], a local journalist in Halifax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07pdd7r|title=The Yorkshire Ripper Investigation, The Reunion – BBC Radio 4|publisher=bbc.co.uk|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref>
In 2017, West Yorkshire Police launched Operation Painthall<!--This correct; it is NOT Paintball!--> to determine if Sutcliffe was guilty of unsolved crimes dating back to 1964. This inquiry also looked at the killings of two sex workers in southern Sweden in 1980. As Sutcliffe was a lorry driver, it was theorised that he had been in Denmark and Sweden, making use of the ferry across the [[Oresund Strait]]. West Yorkshire Police later stated that they were "absolutely certain" that Sutcliffe had never been in Sweden.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Joan|title=The Yorkshire Ripper was not a 'prostitute killer' – now his forgotten victims need justice|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/yorkshire-ripper-not-prostitute-killer-forgotten-victims-need/|accessdate=13 January 2018|work=The Telegraph|date=30 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Jolly|first1=Joanna|title=The Ripper and the Swedish murders|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-sh/the_ripper_and_the_swedish_murders|accessdate=13 January 2018|work=BBC News|date=12 January 2018}}</ref>

Banerjee | image = | fullname = Pradip Kumar Banerjee | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1936|6|23|df=yes}}<ref>[http://www.iloveindia.com/sports/football/players/pk-banerjee.html P. K. Banerjee Profile]</ref><ref>[http://www.indianfootball.de/data/halloffame/banerjee_pk.html P. K. BANERJEE]</ref> | birth_place = [[Jalpaiguri]], [[Bengal Presidency]], [[British India]] | death_date = | death_place = | height = 5ft 8{{frac|1|2}} inches | position = [[Forward (association football)|Striker]]
| youthyears1 = 1951 | youthclubs1 = [[Bihar football team|Bihar]] | years1 = 1954 | years2 = 1955–1967 | clubs1 = [[Aryan F.C.]] | clubs2 = [[Eastern Railway F.C.]] | caps1 = | caps2 = | goals1 = | goals2 =
| nationalyears1 = 1952–1967 | nationalteam1 = [[India national football team|India]]<ref>http://www.indianfootball.de/data/halloffame/banerjee_pk.html</ref><ref>https://www.sportskeeda.com/football/top-5-indian-national-team-strikers-all-time</ref> | nationalcaps1 = 86 | nationalgoals1 = 65
| manageryears1 = 1972–1981 | manageryears2 = 1985 | managerclubs1 = [[India national football team|India]] <ref name="sportal"/> | managerclubs2 = [[India national football team|India]] }}
'''Pradip Kumar Banerjee''' (born 23 June 1936) or '''P. K. Banerjee''' as he is called often, is a distinguished former Indian footballer and football coach. He made 84 appearances for [[India national football team|India]], scoring 65 goals during the course of his career.<ref>https://www.outlookindia.com/newswire/story/pk-banerjee-gets-fifa-centennial-order-of-merit/230174</ref><ref>https://www.sportskeeda.com/football/legends-of-indian-football-p-k-banerjee</ref><ref>http://www.goal.com/en-india/news/136/india/2016/06/23/24888512/celebrating-pkbanerjees-birthday-15-facts-you-must-know</ref> He was one of the first recipients of [[Arjuna Award]], when the awards were instituted in 1961. He was awarded the prestigious [[Padma Shri]] in 1990 and was named Indian Footballer of the 20th century by IFFHS. In 2004, he was awarded the [[FIFA Order of Merit]], the highest honour awarded by [[FIFA]].
==Early life==
Pradip Kumar Banerjee was born on 23rd June 1936, in [[Jalpaiguri]] in [[Bengal Presidency]] (now [[West Bengal]]). He studied in Jalpaiguri Zilla School and completed his schooling from K.M.P.M. School in [[Jamshedpur]].
==Career==
At the age of 15, Banerjee represented Bihar in [[Santosh Trophy]], playing in the right wing. In 1954 he moved on to Kolkata and joined [[Aryan F.C.|Aryan]]. Later he moved on to represent [[Eastern Railway FC|Eastern Railway]]. He made his debut for the national team in the 1955 Quadrangular tournament in [[Dacca]] (presently [[Dhaka]]), [[East Pakistan]] (now capital of [[Bangladesh]]) at the age of 19.<ref>[http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/FootballStudies/2002/FS0502f.pdf Rahim, Amal Dutta, P.K. and Nayeem: The Coaches Who Shaped Indian Football]. Retrieved 12 November 2006.</ref>
He represented India in three Asian Games namely, the [[1958 Asian Games]] in [[Tokyo]], the [[1962 Asian Games]] in [[Jakarta]], where India clinched the gold medal in football and then the [[1966 Asian Games]] in [[Bangkok]]. He was part of the national team that played at the [[1956 Summer Olympics]] in [[Melbourne]]. He captained India at the [[1960 Summer Olympics]] in [[Rome]], where he scored an equalizer against [[France National Football Team|France]] in a 1-1 draw. He represented India thrice at the [[Merdeka Cup]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]], where India won silver medal in 1959 and 1964 and bronze in 1965. Recurring injuries forced him to drop out of the national team and subsequently to his retirement in 1967.
===Selected international goals===
{| class="wikitable collapsible" ! Date !! Venue !! Opponent !! Result !! Competition !! Goals |- | 18 December 1955 || [[Dacca]], [[East Pakistan]] || {{fb|Ceylon}} || 4–3 || [[Colombo Cup|1955 Colombo Cup]] || 2 |- | 26 December 1955 || [[Dacca]], [[East Pakistan]] || {{fb|PAK}} || 2–1 || [[Colombo Cup|1955 Colombo Cup]] || 1 |- | 12 December 1956 || [[Sydney Sports Ground]], [[Sydney]] || {{fb|AUS}} || 7–1 || [[Exhibition game|International Friendly]] || 2 |- | 29 August 1960 || [[Stadio Olimpico Comunale]], [[Grosseto]] || {{fb|FRA}} || 1–1 || [[Football at the 1960 Summer Olympics|1960 Olympics]] || 1 |- | 9 August 1961 || [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]] || {{fb|Malaya}} || 2–1 || [[Merdeka Cup|1961 Merdeka Tournament]] || 1 |- | 27 August 1962 || [[Senayan Stadium]], [[Jakarta]] || {{fb|JPN|1870}} || 2–0 || [[Football at the 1962 Asian Games|1962 Asian Games]] || 1 |- | 30 August 1962 || [[Senayan Stadium]], [[Jakarta]] || {{fb|THA}} || 4–1 || [[Football at the 1962 Asian Games|1962 Asian Games]] || 2 |- | 4 September 1962 || [[Senayan Stadium]], [[Jakarta]] || {{fb|KOR|1949}} || 2–1 || [[Football at the 1962 Asian Games|1962 Asian Games]] || 1 |- | 1 September 1964 || [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]] || {{fb|KOR|1949}} || 2–1 || [[Merdeka Cup|1964 Merdeka Tournament]] || 1 |- | 10 December 1966 || [[Suphachalasai Stadium]], [[Bangkok]] || {{fb|JPN|1870}} || 1–2 || [[Football at the 1966 Asian Games|1966 Asian Games]] || 1 |- |}
==Managerial career== P. K. Bannerjee's first stint at coaching came with the [[East Bengal Club|East Bengal Football Club]]. He guided [[Mohun Bagan A.C.|Mohan Bagan Athletic Club]] to a historic feat, winning the IFA Shield, Rovers Cup and Durand Cup respectively to achieve their first-ever triple-crown triumph in one season. He became the national coach in 1972, starting with the qualifying matches of the 1972 Munich Olympics. He went on to coach the Indian Football Team till 1986.<ref name="sportal">[http://sportal.nic.in/legenddetails.asp?sno=618&moduleid=&maincatid=40&subid=0&comid=55 Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070324143657/http://sportal.nic.in/legenddetails.asp?sno=618&moduleid=&maincatid=40&subid=0&comid=55 |date=24 March 2007 }}. Retrieved 12 November 2006</ref> He joined the Tata Football Academy at Jamshedpur and served as its Technical Director from 1991 to 1997.<ref>[http://www.tatafootballacademy.com/ex-directors.asp Tata Football Academy Website]. Retrieved 12 November 2006.</ref> He was awarded the player of the Millennium in 2005 by FIFA. He had also won the International Fair Play Award from the Olympic Committee, a feat that is yet to be repeated by any Indian footballer. In 1999, Banerjee again took up the post of the technical director of the Indian Football team.<ref>[[The Statesman (India)|The Statesman]]. (29 July 1999). ''PK in the Dark about TD for [[Mauritius]] Trip.''</ref>
==Honours==
===India=== *Asian Games Gold Medal: [[1962 Asian Games]] *[[Merdeka Tournament|Merdeka Tournament Silver Medal]]: 1959, 1964.
===Individual=== *[[Arjuna Award]]: 1961 *[[Padma Shri]]: 1990<ref name="Padma Awards">{{cite web | url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/LST-PDAWD-2013.pdf | title=Padma Awards | publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India | date=2015 | accessdate=July 21, 2015}}</ref> *Indian Footballer of 20th Century (Awarded by [[FIFA]]) *[[FIFA Order of Merit]]: 2004 <ref name="hindu1">[http://www.hinduonnet.com/2004/06/23/stories/2004062309591800.htm The Hindu Article] ''dated'' 23 June 2004. Retrieved 12 November 2006.</ref> Banerjee is the only footballer from Asia who has been awarded the FAIR PLAY Award.

[[Ontario]], [[Canada]] |billed = [[South Africa]]
(as The Interrogator) |trainer = [[Stephen Petitpas]]
[[Bret Hart]]
[[Leo Burke]] |debut = 1990 |retired = 2011 |}} '''Robert Maillet''' (born October 26, 1969) is a Canadian [[actor]] and retired [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]]. He is known for his time in the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF) from 1997 to 1999, where he performed under the [[ring name]] '''Kurrgan''' and was a member of [[The Truth Commission]] and [[The Oddities (professional wrestling)|The Oddities]]. He is also known for his roles in films such as ''[[300 (film)|300]]'' (2007), ''[[Sherlock Holmes (2009 film)|Sherlock Holmes]]'' (2009), ''[[Immortals (2011 film)|Immortals]]'' (2011), ''[[Pacific Rim (film)|Pacific Rim]]'' (2013), ''[[Brick Mansions]]'' (2014), ''[[Hercules (2014 film)|Hercules]]'' (2014), and ''[[Deadpool 2]]'' (2018). ==Early life== Maillet was born in [[Georgetown, Ontario|Georgetown]], [[Ontario]].https://www.facebook.com/robert.maillet.3?fref=ts Less than a year later, Maillet's family moved to [[Ste-Marie-de-Kent, New Brunswick|Ste-Marie-de-Kent]], [[New Brunswick]], a French-Acadian village where he grew up.{{cite web |url=http://www.wizardworld.com/robertmaillet.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303180705/http://www.wizardworld.com/robertmaillet.html |archivedate=2016-03-03 |df= }} ==Professional wrestling career== Maillet made an initial appearance in the WWF on November 11, 1991 when he wrestled as The Cajun Giant, defeating [[Bob Bradley (wrestler)|Bob Bradley]] in a dark match at a television taping in Utica, NY.http://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/91.htm He then spent some time in Japan working for the W*ING promotion as '''Goliath El Gigante'''. He was signed to the [[WWE|WWF]] in 1997, alongside [[Don Callis|The Jackyl]], as a member of [[The Truth Commission]]. He was billed as '''The Interrogator'''. The group was sent to the [[United States Wrestling Association]] (USWA) before being called up to the main WWF roster, where Maillet's ring name evolved into '''Kurrgan The Interrogator''' (whose name was inspired by [[The Kurgan]], and was occasionally referred to as '''The Kurrgan''' on television). Under the tutelage of The Jackyl, a charismatic cult leader, Kurrgan was a [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heel]] known for applying the [[Professional wrestling holds|Iron Claw]] to his opponents and not breaking the hold until The Jackyl slapped him across the face. After The Truth Commission disbanded, Maillet (now billed simply as '''Kurrgan''') continued as a singles wrestler managed by The Jackyl. He later went on to be part of [[The Oddities (professional wrestling)|The Oddities]], The Jackyl's new stable; however, once The Jackyl was removed as the advisor of The Oddities and replaced by the [[Insane Clown Posse]], The Oddities turned [[Face (professional wrestling)|face]] and became fan favourites. Maillet later worked for [[Jacques Rougeau]]'s wrestling events as Kurgan. On July 8, 2005, he wrestled [[Jim Duggan]] during the half-time show of a [[Canadian Football League]] game in [[Montreal]]. Using the name '''Giant Kurgan''', he worked for Emile Dupre's [[Atlantic Grand Prix Wrestling]] (AGPW) and the [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]]-based Legend City Wrestling (LCW). ==Acting career== Maillet appeared in the 2006 film ''[[300 (film)|300]]'', an adaptation of [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller's]] graphic novel of the [[300 (comics)|same name]]. He played the Über-Immortal, a savage [[berserker]] who was part of the enemy's [[Immortals (Persian Empire)|imperial guard]].{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/new-brunswick/story/2007/03/09/nb-maillet300.html | work=CBC News | title=N.B. wrestler makes Hollywood debut in 300 | date=2007-03-09}} In November 2008, during a fight scene for the 2009 film ''[[Sherlock Holmes (2009 film)|Sherlock Holmes]]'', he accidentally punched [[Robert Downey Jr.]] in the face, bloodying Downey and knocking him down.{{cite news|author=Yvon Gauvin|title=New Brunswick actor knocks down star|work=[[Times & Transcript]]|date=2009-01-05|url=http://timestranscript.canadaeast.com/news/article/529930|accessdate=2009-01-05}} Downey later stated on an episode of the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' that Maillet was "10 times more upset about it" than he was.{{Cite video|title=Robert Downey Jr. on David Letterman|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jzfsSAlRLco|series=''Late Show with David Letterman''|serieslink=CBS|network=[[CBS]]|airdate=December 16, 2009}} Maillet played a Russian professional boxer who took a dive in the 2011 film ''[[The Big Bang (2011 film)|The Big Bang]]''. Later that year, he appeared in the film ''[[Monster Brawl]]'' as [[Frankenstein's monster|Frankenstein]] in a wrestling tournament of eight classic monsters that fight to the death.{{IMDb title|1716753|Monster Brawl}} He played [[Polyphemus]] in the 2013 film ''[[Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters]]'', Blackwell in the 2013 film adaptation of ''[[The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones]]'', and the executioner in the 2014 film ''[[Hercules (2014 film)|Hercules]]''. He also had a recurring role on the Syfy original series ''[[Haven (TV series)|Haven]]'' billed as a "Heavy", a thug for the series antagonist. In 2018, Maillet had a small part in the superhero film ''[[Deadpool 2]]'' as Sluggo, a mutant mercenary who is in prison alongside the titular character.{{cite web|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/robert-maillet-deadpool-actor-new-brunswick-1.4677557|title=Actor, former wrestler Robert Maillet lands role in Deadpool 2|last=Blanch|first=Vanessa|date=May 26, 2018|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]]}} He also had a part in the 2018 Netflix film ''[[Game Over, Man!]]''. ==Personal life== Maillet has been married to Laura Eaton since June 13, 1997. He has both step-daughters, as well as a daughter [[adoption|adopted]] from [[Ethiopia]]. Being an [[Acadian]], his first language is [[French language|French]] and he is conversant in [[English language|English]].{{cite web |url= http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/MatMatters/2012/01/16/19249651.html |title= When a giant came for dinner |first= Greg|last= Oliver|work=slam.canoe.ca |date= 2012-01-16|accessdate=2012-01-16}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Director ! 2015 |''[[Haven (TV series)|Haven]]'' |Heavy |5 episodes; also credited as Robert Norman Maillet in Season 5 |- | 2014-2015 |''[[The Strain (TV series)|The Strain]]'' |The Master |11 episodes |- | 2014 |''[[Dark Rising: Warrior of Worlds (TV series)|Dark Rising: Warrior of Worlds]]'' |Bedard |5 episodes |} ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[NWA: Extreme Canadian Championship Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA/ECCW Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA/ECCW Heavyweight Championship#Title history|2 times]]) *'''Legend City Wrestling''' **LCW Newfoundland Tag Team Championship (1 time) - with Mr. Fantastic http://www.legendcitywrestling.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=93&Itemid=172 *'''Real Action Wrestling''' **RAW Heavyweight Championship (1 time) *'''[[United States Wrestling Association]]''' **[[USWA World Tag Team Championship]] ([[USWA World Tag Team Championship#Title H istory|3 times]]) {{ndash}} with [[Barry Buchanan|Recon]] *'''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards]]''' **[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Worst Tag Team|Worst Tag Team]] (1998) {{ndash}} with [[John Tenta|Golga]] **[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Worst Gimmick|Worst Gimmick]] (1998) {{ndash}} as Kurrgan,as part of The Oddities == See also == {{Portal bar|Professional wrestling}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|537631}} {{MTV Movie Award for Best Fight}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maillet, Robert}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Acadian people]] [[Category:Canadian male film actors]] [[Category:Canadian male television actors]] [[Category:Canadian male professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male actors from New Brunswick]] [[Category:People from Kent County, New Brunswick]] [[Category:Professional wrestlers from New Brunswick]] [[Category:Professional wrestlers from Ontario]]

[[File:Faroe stamp 365 sanna av skardi and anna suffia rasmussen.jpg|thumb|Sanna av Skarði (left) depicted with [[Anna Suffía Rasmussen]] on a Faroese postage stamp]]
'''Sanna av Skarði''' (born '''Súsanna Kathrina Jacobsen''',<ref name="DKL">[http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/597/bio/1273/ ''Dansk Kvindebiografisk Leksikon'': Sigrid av Skarði Joensen (1908–1975).]</ref> April 19, 1876 – February 12, 1978)<ref name="DSD">[http://denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Uddannelse_og_undervisning/H%C3%B8jskoleforstander/Simun_av_Skar%C3%B0i ''Den Store Danske'': Simun av Skarði.]</ref><ref name="Bundgaard">[http://slaegt.gnurk.dk/torben/legacy/166.htm Bundgaard, Torben: Susanna Kathrine Jacobsen.]</ref> was a [[Faroe Islanders|Faroese]] educator.
Sanna av Skarði was born in [[Tórshavn]], the daughter of Jacob Jacobsen and Elsebeth Jacobsen née Djonesen.<ref name="Bundgaard"/> In 1901 she married [[Símun av Skarði]],<ref name="DSD"/> who co-founded the [[Faroese Folk High School]] ({{lang-fo|Føroya Fólkaháskúli}}) together with [[Rasmus Rasmussen (writer)|Rasmus Rasmussen]] in [[Klaksvík]] in 1899.<ref>Pons, Christophe. 2011. The Anthropology of Christianity in the Faroe Islands. In: Firouz Gaini (ed.), ''Among the Islanders of the North: An Anthropology of the Faroe Islands'', pp. 80–131. Tórshavn: Fróðskapur / Faroe University Press, p. 91.</ref> She taught together with her husband at the school. She died in [[Tórshavn]] at the age of 101.<ref name="Bundgaard"/>
Sanna and Símun were the parents of the journalist [[Sigrið av Skarði Joensen]] (1908–1975)<ref name="DKL"/> and the linguist [[Jóhannes av Skarði]] (1911–1999).
In 2000, she was featured on a Faroese stamp together with her sister-in-law [[Anna Suffía Rasmussen]]. Aside from [[Ruth Smith (artist)|Ruth Smith]]'s self-portrait, this is the only Faroese postage stamp depicting prominent women.

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |image = Sat Bir Singh Khalsa.jpg |image_caption = Sat Bir Singh Khalsa at University of Toronto |name = Sat Bir Singh Khalsa | birth_date = {{Birth date|1951|12|20|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] | spouse = Siri Krishna Kaur | children = Hansmukh Kaur (daughter), Harimandir Singh (son) }}
'''Sat Bir Singh Khalsa''' is a researcher in the field of body mind medicine, specializing in yoga therapy. Originally from Toronto, he earned his Ph.D. at the [[University of Toronto]], where he also began his practice of Kundalini Yoga under the tutelage of [[Yogi Bhajan]]. He is (since 2006) an Assistant Professor of Medicine at [[Harvard Medical School]] and an Associate Neuroscientist (since 1998) in the Division of Sleep and Circadian Disorders, at the Departments of Medicine and Neurology, [[Brigham and Women's Hospital]], in Boston Massachusetts. Since 2007, Sat Bir Singh Khalsa has served as the Director of Research at both the Kripalu Center for Yoga and Health in Massachusetts and the Kundalini Research Institute in New Mexico.
==Research Studies== Sat Bir Singh Khalsa has participated in numerous mind-body studies. His work has been published in more than thirty papers. His most widely cited work explores human sleep cycles.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1113/jphysiol.2003.040477 | volume=549 | title=A Phase Response Curve to Single Bright Light Pulses in Human Subjects | journal=The Journal of Physiology | pages=945–952 | pmid=12717008 | pmc=2342968 | last1 = Khalsa | first1 = SB | last2 = Jewett | first2 = ME | last3 = Cajochen | first3 = C | last4 = Czeisler | first4 = CA}}, (1999) EEG and ocular correlates of circadian melatonin phase and human performance decrements during sleep loss http://ajpregu.physiology.org/content/277/3/R640, {{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006899397003375 | doi=10.1016/S0006-8993(97)00337-5 | volume=757 | title=Circadian rhythms in mouse suprachiasmatic nucleus explants on multimicroelectrode plates | journal=Brain Research | pages=285–290}}, {{cite journal | doi = 10.1210/jc.2010-2098 | volume=96 | title=Exposure to Room Light before Bedtime Suppresses Melatonin Onset and Shortens Melatonin Duration in Humans | journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism | pages=E463–E472| pmc=3047226 }}</ref>
Several of his other papers explore the application of yoga as therapy for insomnia, performance anxiety, mental health in a secondary school setting, drug addiction, depression, and as a predictor of low body mass and low medication usage.<ref>(2004) Treatment of chronic insomnia with yoga: a preliminary study with sleep-wake diaries {{cite journal | url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10484-004-0387-0 | doi=10.1007/s10484-004-0387-0 | volume=29 | title=Treatment of Chronic Insomnia with Yoga: A Preliminary Study with Sleep?Wake Diaries | journal=Applied Psychophysiology and Biofeedback | pages=269–278}}, (2012) Evaluation of the mental health benefits of yoga in a secondary school: a preliminary randomized control trial https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11414-011-9249-8#page-1, (2008) Evaluation of a residential kundalini yoga lifestyle pilot program for addiction in India {{cite journal | url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/15332640802081968 | doi=10.1080/15332640802081968 | volume=7 | title=Evaluation of a Residential Kundalini Yoga Lifestyle Pilot Program for Addiction in India | journal=Journal of Ethnicity in Substance Abuse | pages=67–79}}, (2011) Increased Hatha yoga experience predicts lower body mass index and reduced medication use in women over 45 years {{cite journal | pmc=3193658 | pmid=22022126 | doi=10.4103/0973-6131.85490 | volume=4 | title=Increased Hatha yoga experience predicts lower body mass index and reduced medication use in women over 45 years | year=2011 | journal=Int J Yoga | pages=77–86 | last1 = Moliver | first1 = N | last2 = Mika | first2 = E | last3 = Chartrand | first3 = M | last4 = Burrus | first4 = S | last5 = Haussmann | first5 = R | last6 = Khalsa | first6 = S}}</ref>
==Media and Public Speaking== Sat Bir Singh Khalsa is often hired to speak about his research world wide, as the findings are helpful for the general public, government and NGOs, schools, universities and corporations alike.
In 2013 lead was hosted to lead an online panel discussion about the effect of yoga on health.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.curetalks.com/event/rsvp/Benefits-of-Yoga-with-Harvard-Researcher/80/|title=Benefits of Yoga with Harvard Researcher|website=Curetalks.com|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> In another example, he was positioned to share his expertise in an online radio show type conversation format with another notable yoga expert Dashama Konah Gordon<ref>{{cite web|url=http://trialx.com/curetalk/2013/04/25/dr-sat-bir-singh-khalsa-in-conversation-with-dashama-on-the-cure-panel-talk-show-on-yoga/|title=Dr.Sat Bir Singh Khalsa In Conversation With Dashama on The Cure Panel Talk Show on YOGA|website=Trialx.com|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref>
In 2017, Sat Bir Singh Khalsa was flown to Coventry, [[United Kingdom|UK]] for a preparatory discussion about yoga and corporate research with Dr Haley Beer, a research professor at [[Warwick University]] and Dashama Konah Gordon the founder of Pranashama Yoga Institute.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wbs.ac.uk/events/view/5449|title=Yoga - Its Benefits in the Workplace|website=Wbs.ac.uk|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> Sat Bir was invited to offer his consulting expertise from his background in medical research at [[Harvard]] to develop a yoga research project to demonstrate through qualitative research how yoga and mediation can help people in corporate settings access the [[Flow (psychology)|Flow]] State to attain greater well being, creativity and productivity.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wbs.ac.uk/wbs2012/assets/PDF/downloads/yoga-class-and-lecture-flier-v2.pdf|title=Warwick Business School Teams Up with Harvard and Pranashama Yoga Institute|website=wbs.ac.uk|accessdate=30 August 2018}}</ref>
==General Publications== * Sat Bir Singh Khalsa. (2009). "Kundalini Yoga as Therapy: A Research Perspective," chapter in Kundalini Rising: Exploring the Awakening of Kundalini. Boulder Colorado, Sounds True, Inc. * Sat Bir Singh Khalsa with Jodie Gould (2012). Your Brain on Yoga. Rosetta Books.
==Sources== *https://sleep.med.harvard.edu/people/faculty/240/sat+bir+singh+khalsa+phd *http://www.kripalu.org/presenter/V0005180/sat_bir_s_khalsa *https://web.archive.org/web/20140408112835/http://www.kundaliniresearchinstitute.org/meet%20the%20staff.htm
==Links to Research Articles== {{Reflist}}
