{{DEFAULTSORT:Khalsa, Sat Bir Singh}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:American Sikhs]] [[Category:Converts to Sikhism]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Researchers]] [[Category:University of Toronto alumni]]

[[File:Trieste-Canal Grande-DSCF1420.JPG|right|thumb|Palazzo Gopcevich in Trieste]] '''Spiridione Gopcevich''' ({{lang-sr|Spiridon Gopčević}}, [[Serbian Cyrillic|Cyrillic]]: Спиридон Гопчевић, Trieste, 1815-1861) was an ethnic-[[Serb]]<ref>http://www.artearti.net/magazine/articolo/genti_di_san_spiridione_i_serbi_a_trieste_1751-1914</ref> shipowner from [[Trieste]].
==Biography== His father, Christopher Gopcevich, born in 1765, originated from the village of Podi near [[Herceg Novi]], in [[Boka Kotorska]] (modern [[Montenegro]]), which had been annexed by the [[Austrian Empire]] in 1815 from the [[Prince-Bishopric of Montenegro]]. The mother was Sofia Kvekich (Herceg Novi 1792 - Trieste 1854).
Spiridione was sent to [[Vienna]] to be educated. He spoke fluently thirteen languages and become a great shipowner in [[Trieste]], then [[Austrian Littoral]] (modern [[Italy]]) and in [[Odessa]], [[Imperial Russia]]. His ships traded on the Mediterranean and the Black Sea routes, and he was in contact with the British Prime Minister [[William Gladstone]] and [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]]. A ruinous crash suffered after reckless speculation during the [[Crimean War]] (1853-1856), prompted him to suicide in 1861.<ref name="comune">{{cite web|url=http://www.retecivica.trieste.it/triestecultura/new/serbiatrieste/default.asp?pagina=gopcevich|title=Gopcevich|publisher=Commune of Trieste|language=Italian|accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref>
His son [[Spiridon Gopčević]] (1855 Trieste-Vienna 1936) was a political journalist and world-renowned astronomer.
Another illustrious descendant of the family was [[Marino Gopcevich]] (1899-1965), a neurologist, who in 1945 founded the Neurological division of the Hospital in Trieste.
Gopcevich built the [[Palazzo Gopcevich]] in Trieste.
==See also== *[[Triestine Serbs]] *[[Serbs in Italy]] *[[Serbian diaspora]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gopcevich, Spiridione}} [[Category:People from Trieste]] [[Category:Businesspeople in shipping]] [[Category:People from Austrian Littoral]] [[Category:1815 births]] [[Category:1861 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century businesspeople]]

'''Stephen Tanzer''' is an [[United States|American]] [[wine]] critic and editor at [http://vinous.com/ Vinous].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/people.asp?privcapId=244089450|title=Vinous Media LLC: CEO and Executives - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-10-27}}</ref> From 1985 until he joined Vinous in 2014, Tanzer was the publisher of the critically acclaimed bimonthly ''International Wine Cellar'',<ref>{{cite web |last= ''Forbes.com''| title= Stephen Tanzer's International Wine Cellar |url= https://www.forbes.com/bow/b2c/review.jhtml?id=7246}}</ref> an independent journal read by wine professionals and other wine lovers in all 50 U.S. states and 34 countries, and the first American wine periodical to be translated into French and Japanese. Tanzer has particular expertise on the wines of [[Bordeaux wine|Bordeaux]], as well as other prominent wine regions, including [[Burgundy wine|Burgundy]], [[California wine|California]], Washington State, and South Africa.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wine-searcher.com/critics-11-stephen+tanzer|title=Stephen Tanzer, IWC Archive|website=www.wine-searcher.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-27}}</ref>
Tanzer has written wine columns for ''[[Food & Wine Magazine]]'' and ''[[Forbes|Forbes FYI]]''. Among his books are ''[https://www.amazon.com/WineAccess-Buyers-Guide-Worlds-Wines/dp/1402728166 The WineAccess Buyer's Guide]'' and [https://www.amazon.ca/Food-Wine-Magazines-Official-Guide/dp/0312179707 ''Food and Wine Magazine's Official Wine Guide''.]
Tanzer's '' International Wine Cellar'', which employed a modern [[wine rating]] system on a 70-100 point quality scale, was considered in direct competition with [[Robert M. Parker, Jr.|Robert Parker]]'s ''[[The Wine Advocate]]'',<ref name="jr">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wine-searcher.com/critics-11-stephen+tanzer|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> though Tanzer's "controlled prose" is in contrast to the more flamboyant style of Parker.<ref name=NYT>{{cite web|last =Asimov |first =Eric ''The New York Times'' |title = Settling in, Glass in Hand, to Read of Wine |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/06/dining/06pour.html |date =December 6, 2006 }}</ref> Tanzer still uses this scale in his ratings and reviews with Vinous.
In February 2010, Tanzer launched the website "Winophilia" in the wine [[blog]] format, which published short articles by Tanzer, ''IWC'' collaborator Josh Raynolds, and other ''IWC'' contributors.
Tanzer's wine reviews are available to [[CellarTracker]] users who are also subscribers to [http://vinous.com/ Vinous].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://vinous.com/statics/iwcfaq|title=IWC FAQ {{!}} Vinous - Explore All Things Wine|website=vinous.com|access-date=2017-10-27}}</ref>
On November 18, 2014 Vinous, founded by [[Antonio Galloni]], announced it had agreed to acquire Stephen Tanzer's IWC and in late 2014 IWC's archive had been transferred in a combined site home, available to both Vinous and IWC readers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/aliciaadamczyk/2014/11/18/wine-publishing-platform-vinous-acquires-critically-acclaimed-international-wine-cellar/#71ec053d2aab|title=Wine Publishing Platform Vinous Acquires Critically Acclaimed International Wine Cellar|last=Adamczyk|first=Alicia|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-10-27|language=en}}</ref> IWC team members Ian D'Agata and Josh Raynolds are also part of the [http://vinous.com/statics/about Vinous team].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://vinous.com/statics/about|title=About {{!}} Vinous - Explore All Things Wine|website=vinous.com|access-date=2017-10-27}}</ref>
Tanzer samples well over 10,000 wines annually, spending several months each year tasting and discussing wines with their makers, both in the U.S. and abroad.
==See also== *[[List of wine personalities]]
==References== <!-- {{refbegin}} * [http://www. {{refend}} ;Footnotes --> {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.wineaccess.com/expert/tanzer/newhome.html Stephen Tanzer's ''International Wine Cellar'' official site] *[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323976104578199462080730782?mod=WSJ_LifeStyle_Lifestyle_5 "A Critic Who Favors Finesse Over Power"], [[Jay McInerney]], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', 28 December 2012
{{Authority control}}

Cole Webley | camera = Multi-camera | runtime = 60 minutes | company = [[BYU Television]] | channel = [[BYU Television]] | first_aired = {{start date|2010|1|4}} | last_aired = present }} '''''The Generations Project''''' is a [[Reality television|reality]] television series produced by and shown on [[BYU Television]] that helps those who have questions about their [[family history]] investigate their own identities by embarking on a journey to uncover the lives and stories of their ancestors. During this journey each participant attempts to retrace their ancestors footsteps often participating in immersion experiences, meeting experts, and even sometimes connecting with family they never knew they had. As each participant on the show sets out on their journey they discover new details about the lives of their ancestors, answer questions about identity, about time and place, and even discover things about themselves. Overall this journey helps participants learn where they have been and make their own conclusions about where they are going. It premiered on January 4, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.byutv.org/thegenerationsproject/ |title=The Generations Project |publisher=BYUtv |date= |accessdate=2014-08-12}}https://www.facebook.com/GenerationsProject?v=info {{as of|January 2012}} the show is in its third season, with a total 33 shows produced.{{cite web|url=http://byutv.org/thegenerationsproject |title=The Generations Project |publisher=BYUtv |date= |accessdate=2014-08-12}} [[File:TheGenerationsProject 2009.jpg|thumb|The Generation Project's prototype logo, used in 2009|right]] ==Episodes== {{Update|this section|date=January 2012}} ===Season 1: 2010=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- valign="top" !width="45"|# ! style="width:150px;"|Original air date ! class="unsortable" style="width:150px;"|Participant !class="unsortable" | Description |- valign="top" |101 |{{dts|March 29, 2010}} |Lakia Holmes |{{cite web|url=http://byutv.org/watch/7ebf850d-6152-4a08-b2b3-265371e696eb/the-generations-project-lakia |title=The Generations Project - revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Tom Forcade | image = | caption =Tom Forcade in 1973 for a [[Boulder, Colorado]] meeting of the [[Underground Press]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1945|9|11|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Phoenix, Arizona]] | death_date ={{Death date and age|mf=y|1978|11|17|1945|9|11}} | death_place = [[New York City]] | height = | occupation = Underground journalist, activist | years_active = | salary = | networth = | website = }} '''Thomas King Forçade''' (September 11, 1945 – November 17, 1978), also known as '''Gary Goodson''',<ref name="gross1991">Gross, Michael (February 18, 1991). Ivana's avenger. ''[[New York Magazine]]''</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[underground journalist]] and [[cannabis rights]] [[activist]] in the 1970s. For many years he ran the [[Underground Press Syndicate]] (later called the Alternative Press Syndicate), and was the founder in summer 1974 of ''[[High Times]]'' magazine.<ref>Bienenstock, David; and editors of ''[[High Times]]'' magazine (2008). [http://www.hightimes.com/microsites/handbook/chap1p3.inc.php Chapter 1 HIGHstory] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407062624/http://www.hightimes.com/microsites/handbook/chap1p3.inc.php |date=2014-04-07 }}. ''The Official High Times Pot Smokers Handbook: Featuring 420 Things to do When You're Stoned.'' [[Chronicle Books]]. {{ISBN|0811862054}}. {{ISBN|9780811862059}}.</ref> ''High Times'' ran articles calling [[marijuana]] a "medical wonder drug" and ridiculing the US [[Drug Enforcement Administration]]. ''High Times'' became a huge success with a circulation of more than 500,000 copies a month and revenues approaching $10 million by 1977 and embraced by the young adult market as the bible of the alternative life culture. By 1977 ''High Times'' was selling as many copies an issue as'' Rolling Stone ''and ''National Lampoon. ''Forcade published several other publications such as'' Stoned, National Weed, Dealer'' and others that always were laced with some of the best humor, pop culture and a forum for some of the best writers, artists and political savvy mostly veiled as the counter culture entertainment magazine. Many of the writers went on to be published in premiere papers and magazines in North America.
==Life and career==
He was born in [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. His father, engineer and [[hot rod]] enthusiast Kenneth Goodson, died in a car crash when Forçade was a child.
Forçade graduated from the [[University of Utah]] in 1967 with a degree in business administration. He went into the [[United States Air Force]] but was discharged after a few months. He used the skills he learned, however, to fly across the border for several years trafficking drugs from Mexico and Colombia,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blacklistedjournalist.com/column68b.html|title=Tom Forcade, Social Architect|author=[[Al Aronowitz]]|website=The Blacklisted Journalist|access-date=2002-02-01}}</ref> and used his proceeds to form a hippie commune and underground magazine called Orpheus. After this, he moved to [[New York City]], where he became famous for founding ''[[High Times]]'' as well as contributing funding to the [[Yippie]] newspaper, ''Yipster Times'',<ref name=Yippie>{{Cite book|title=Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago, '68, to 1984 | author=New Yippie Book Collective | isbn=9780912873008 |publisher=Bleecker Publishing|date=1983}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n-SG3oWUjhMC&pg=PA152&lpg=PA152&dq=yippie+concerts&source=bl&ots=G51pTNsBrI&sig=Nw23nlCkXEYVzpaoavv6qR1lqng&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi9xeXXvOTWAhWC5iYKHWPjD_YQ6AEIVzAJ#v=onepage&q=yippie%20concerts&f=false|title=Smoke Signals: A Social History of Marijuana - Medical, Recreational and Scientific|author=Martin A. Lee|publisher=Simon & Schuster|date=2012}}</ref> and bankrolling an ailing Punk Magazine.<ref name="armstrong1981">Armstrong, David (1981). ''A trumpet to arms: alternative media in America.'' J.P. Tarcher, {{ISBN|978-0-87477-158-9}}</ref>
In 1970, Forcade was the first documented activist to use [[pieing]] as a form of protest, hitting Chairman [[Otto Larsen (sociology)|Otto Larsen]] during the [[President's Commission on Obscenity and Pornography]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/10/weekinreview/take-sugar-eggs-beliefs-and-aim.html|website=New York Times|title=Take Sugar, Eggs, Beliefs . . . And Aim|author=Vinciguerra, Thomas|date=10 December 2000}}</ref><ref name="nytpie">Staff report (May 13, 1970). [https://www.nytimes.com/1970/05/14/archives/witness-presents-pornography-commissioner-with-a-pie-in-the-face.html Witness Presents Pornography Commissioner With a Pie (in the Face)]. ''[[New York Times]]''</ref><ref>Weiner, Rex (April 1, 2014). [http://www.theparisreview.org/blog/2014/04/01/heres-pie-in-your-eye Here’s Pie in Your Eye]. ''[[The Paris Review]].''</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/throwing-custard-pies-looks-like-fun-its-also-art|title=Throwing Custard Pies Looks Like Fun. It’s Also Art.|author=[[Anthony Haden-Guest]]|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|access-date=18 February 2018}}</ref>
According to the 1990 nonfiction book ''12 Days on the Road: The Sex Pistols and America'', by Noel E. Monk and Jimmy Guterman, Forcade and his film crew followed the [[Sex Pistols]] through their chaotic January 1978 concerts of the U.S. South and West, using high-pressure tactics in an unsuccessful attempt to persuade the band's management and record company to let him document the tour.
Forcade was a co-founder of the [[Underground Press Syndicate]], which he ran for many years. The name was changed to the Alternative Press Syndicate in 1973.
==Death== Forçade committed suicide by gunshot to the head in November 1978 in his [[Greenwich Village]] apartment after the death of his best friend, Jack Coombs.<ref name="Torgoff2004">{{cite book |first=Martin |last=Torgoff |authorlink=Martin Torgoff |title=Can't Find My Way Home: America in the Great Stoned Age, 1945–2000 |year=2004 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=978-0-7432-5863-0 |page=269 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PpqQTLE_qBEC&pg=PA269 }}</ref> Forcade had attempted suicide before and bequeathed [[trusts]] to benefit ''High Times'' and [[NORML]].
==References== {{Reflist}}

'''Troye Sivan Mellet''' ({{IPAc-en|t|r|ɔɪ|_|s|ᵻ|ˈ|v|ɑː|n}} {{respell|TROY|_|sih|VAHN}}; born 5 June 1995),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/troyesivan/status/739352032461524992|title = troye sivan on Twitter: "IM 21"|website = [[Twitter]]|date = 5 June 2016|accessdate = 5 June 2018}}</ref> known professionally as '''Troye Sivan''', is a South African-born Australian singer, songwriter, actor, and [[YouTube]] personality. After gaining popularity as a singer on YouTube and in Australian talent competitions, Sivan signed with [[Universal Music Australia|EMI Australia]] in 2013 and released his debut extended play, ''[[TRXYE]]'' (2014), which peaked at number five on the U.S. [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. Its lead single, "[[Happy Little Pill]]", reached number 10 on Australian music charts. In 2015, he released his second extended play ''[[Wild (Troye Sivan EP)|Wild]]'' followed by his debut studio album ''[[Blue Neighbourhood]]'', whose lead single "[[Youth (Troye Sivan song)|Youth]]" became Sivan's first single to enter the top 40 of the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart, peaking at number 23.<ref name="twitter.com">{{cite tweet |user=troyesivan |number=653975462452965376 |title=💙 BLUE NEIGHBOURHOOD – PREORDER OCTOBER 15 – OUT DECEMBER 4 💙 |date=14 October 2015 |access-date=May 28, 2018 |last=Sivan |first=Troye}}</ref> His second studio album ''[[Bloom (Troye Sivan album)|Bloom]]'' (2018) reached number three in Australia and number four on the ''Billboard'' 200 chart. Its lead single "[[My My My! (Troye Sivan song)|My My My!]]" became Sivan's second number-one single on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Dance Club Songs]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8457748/troye-sivan-my-my-my-no-1-dance-club-songs-chart|title=Troye Sivan's 'My My My' Moves to No. 1 on Dance Club Songs Chart|website=Billboard.com|accessdate=2 September 2018}}</ref>
As an actor, Sivan portrayed the younger version of the [[Wolverine (character)|titular character]] in the 2009 [[X-Men]] film ''[[X-Men Origins: Wolverine]]'' and starred as the title character in the ''[[Spud (film)|Spud]]'' film trilogy. As a YouTube personality, Sivan used to upload [[video blog]]s regularly and, as of 2016, has over 4 million subscribers and over 241 million total views.<ref name="Social Blade">{{cite web |url=http://socialblade.com/youtube/user/troyesivan18 |title=Troyesivan18 YouTube Stats, Channel Statistics |work=Social Blade |accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref> His video, "The 'Boyfriend' Tag", with fellow vlogger [[Tyler Oakley]] earned them a [[2014 Teen Choice Awards#Choice Web|Teen Choice Award]] in the "Choice Web Collaboration" category. In October 2014, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' named Sivan as one of the "25 Most Influential Teens of 2014".<ref>{{cite news |title=The 25 Most Influential Teens of 2014 |url=http://time.com/3486048/most-influential-teens-2014/ |website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=13 October 2014 |accessdate=3 January 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VJ9l0sZQ?url=http://time.com/3486048/most-influential-teens-2014/ |archivedate=3 January 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
== Early life == Sivan was born in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZTIH8FrqQyM |title=Australian Boy Does Accents! |work=YouTube |date=17 November 2012 |accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref><ref name="bio">{{cite web |title=Biography |url=http://www.troyesivan.com/about.html |work=Troye Sivan (Official website) |accessdate=22 January 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iXxUD9fc?url=http://www.troyesivan.com/about.html |archivedate=26 July 2009}}</ref> the son of Laurelle and Shaun Mellet.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/good-weekend/troye-sivan-the-most-famous-teenager-youve-never-heard-of-20150209-13a11r.html |title=Troye Sivan, the most famous teenager you've never heard of |last=Law |first=Benjamin |date=27 February 2015 |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |access-date = 11 April 2016}}</ref> His family moved to Australia when he was two years old due to rising crime in South Africa.<ref name="earbiscuit">{{cite podcast |first1=Rhett |last1=McLaughlin |first2=Charles |last2=Neal |authorlink=Rhett and Link |title=Ep. 29 Troye Sivan |url=https://soundcloud.com/earbiscuits/ep-29-troye-sivan-ear-biscuits |work=Ear Biscuits |date=19 April 2014 |accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> Sivan grew up living in [[Perth]], Western Australia with his parents and three siblings Steele, Tyde and Sage. His father is a [[real estate agent]] and his mother is a homemaker.<ref name="earbiscuit" /> He is [[Jew]]ish;<ref>{{cite web |first=Cameron |last=Adams |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/youtube-sensation-troye-sivan-on-his-debut-album-being-gay-and-being-a-gay-role-model/news-story/9a1b34a13fa114f884d7eda12c0b69e6 |title=YouTube sensation Troye Sivan on his debut album, being gay and being a gay role model |work=[[news.com.au]] |date=December 2, 2015 |accessdate=May 8, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Jake |last=Hall |url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/music/article/34393/1/troye-sivan-heaven-video-interview |title=TTroye Sivan on the queer politics of his new video |work=[[Dazed]] |date=January 19, 2017 |accessdate=May 8, 2018}}</ref> his father was born to a Jewish family and his mother [[Conversion to Judaism|converted to Judaism]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Frank |url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/music/article/39346/1/troye-sivan-boy-erased-new-album-interview |title=Troye Sivan: atomic blonde |work=[[Dazed]] |date=March 14, 2018 |accessdate=May 8, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://troyesivan.tumblr.com/post/31919189880/how-jewish-are-you-like-are-you-orthodox-or-reform-or |title=Troye Sivan's Tumblr — How Jewish are you? Like are you orthodox or reform or? |website=Troyesivan.tumblr.com |date=20 September 2012 |accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref> Sivan attended [[Carmel School, Perth|Carmel School]], a private [[Modern Orthodox Judaism|Modern Orthodox]] school, until 2009 when he started [[distance education]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Gabrielle |last=Reilly |title=Troye Sivan Interview |url=http://www.theglobaltownhall.com/troye_sivan |website=The Global Townhall |accessdate=14 January 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VZkds3Ph?url=http://www.theglobaltownhall.com/troye_sivan |archivedate=14 January 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
== Career ==
=== Music === [[File:Troye Sivan (14523593376).jpg|left|thumb|Sivan in 2014]] Sivan's musical career started when he sang at the 2006, 2007 and 2008 [[Channel Seven Perth Telethon]].<ref name="PerthNow">{{cite news |last=Symonds |first=Kristy |title=Perth boy making it big in Hollywood |url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/entertainment/perth-boy-making-it-big-in-hollywood/story-e6frg30c-1226321060650 |accessdate=15 January 2014 |newspaper=[[Perth Now]] |date=7 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="stm">{{cite news |last=Harvey |first=Shannon |title=Perth boy to play young Hugh Jackman in Wolverine movie |url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/perth-boy-to-play-young-hugh/story-e6frg12c-1111115680990 |accessdate=15 January 2014 |newspaper=[[Perth Now]] |date=28 February 2008}}</ref> His 2006 performance included a duet with ''[[Australian Idol]]'' winner [[Guy Sebastian]].<ref name="stm" /> Sivan made it to the finals of ''StarSearch'' 2007.<ref name="PerthNow" /> His debut EP, ''[[Dare to Dream (EP)|Dare to Dream]]'', was released in June 2007. In February 2010, Sivan opened "[[We Are the World 25 for Haiti (YouTube edition)|We Are the World 25 for Haiti (YouTube Edition)]]", the collaborative music charity video produced by [[Lisa Lavie]] to help raise money for the victims of the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.yourmusics.in/artist/biography/troye-sivan-35225.html|title=Free Troye Sivan biography {{!}} SONG365|website=Yourmusics.in|access-date=6 October 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171006211539/https://www.yourmusics.in/artist/biography/troye-sivan-35225.html|archivedate=6 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His most recent hit "Youth", from his ''[[Blue Neighbourhood]]'' album that he released in 2015 reached number 23 in the billboard Top 40 single.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.fuse.tv/2016/03/troye-sivan-youth-goes-top-40 |title=Troye Sivan's 'Youth' Soars Into Top 40 |work=Fuse|access-date=6 October 2017}}</ref>
On 5 June 2013, Sivan was signed to EMI Australia, a [[Universal Music Australia]] label, but kept it a secret until a year later. On 15 August 2014 he released a five-song EP entitled ''[[TRXYE]]'', led by its first single "[[Happy Little Pill]]", which was released on 25 July 2014.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Caulfield |first1=Keith |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6140809/youtube-star-troye-sivan-signs-with-emi-australia-announces-ep |title=YouTube Star Troye Sivan Signs With EMI Australia, Announces EP |website=Billboard |date=27 June 2014 |accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref> ''TRXYE'' debuted at No. 1 on iTunes in over 55 countries.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Stern |first1=Bradley |url=http://www.idolator.com/7531054/troye-sivan-shoots-to-1-on-itunes-with-debut-ep-trxye |title=Troye Sivan Shoots To #1 On iTunes (In 55 Countries!) With Debut EP, 'TRXYE' |website=Idolator |date=15 August 2014 |accessdate=25 September 2014}}</ref> The album debuted at No. 5 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] the following week, scoring Sivan his first Top 10 album.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Caulfield |first1=Keith |url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/chart-alert/6221699/troye-sivan-set-for-top-10-debut-on-billboard-200 |title=Troye Sivan Set for Top 10 Debut on Billboard 200 |website=Billboard |date=15 August 2014 |accessdate=25 September 2014}}</ref> "Happy Little Pill" peaked at number 10 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Chart]] and was certified gold by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] for shipments exceeding 35,000 copies.<ref name="ARIAcert">{{cite certification |region=Australia |type=single |certyear=2014 |accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref> Sivan released his second major-label EP, ''[[Wild (Troye Sivan EP)|Wild]]'', on 4 September 2015. The EP was supported by a music video trilogy entitled ''Blue Neighbourhood'', comprising the three songs "[[Wild (Troye Sivan song)|Wild]]", "Fools" and "[[Talk Me Down]]" and released from September 2015 to December 2015. Additionally, the EP served as an introduction to his album Blue Neighbourhood,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://renownedforsound.com/index.php/album-review-troye-sivan-blue-neighbourhood/ |title=Album Review: Troye Sivan – Blue Neighbourhood |last=Smith |first=Michael |date=5 December 2015 |website=Renowned for Sound|access-date = 11 April 2016}}</ref> which was released on 4 December 2015.<ref name="twitter.com" /> Sivan supported his debut studio album ''Blue Neighbourhood'' and his EP ''Wild'' with his first tour, 2015's [[Troye Sivan Live]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailydot.com/entertainment/troye-sivan-fools-video-us-tour/ |title=Troye Sivan releases music video for 'Fools,' announces first U.S. tour |last=Votta |first=Rae |date=25 September 2015 |website=[[The Daily Dot]]|access-date = 26 September 2015}}</ref> Sivan further supported his debut studio album with 2016's [[Blue Neighbourhood Tour]] and Suburbia Tour. On 26 May 2017, Troye collaborated with [[Martin Garrix]] to produce the song called [[There for You]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.out.com/music/2017/5/26/why-troye-sivans-martin-garrix-collab-there-you-important-lgbtq-listeners |title=Why Troye Sivan's Martin Garrix Collab 'There For You' is Important for LGBTQ Listeners |date=2017-05-26|access-date=2018-04-30}}</ref>
[[File:Troye Sivan July 2015 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Sivan in 2015]] On 10 January 2018, Sivan released the single "[[My My My! (Troye Sivan song)|My My My!]]", along with an accompanying music video.<ref name="auto1">{{Cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/event/music/577378024/in-my-my-my-video-troye-sivan-cements-his-image-as-a-gay-pop-icon |title=In 'My My My!' Video, Troye Sivan Cements His Image As A Gay Pop Icon |work=NPR.org|access-date=11 January 2018}}</ref> He confirmed that his second album was inspired by his boyfriend, an American model named Jacob Bixenman.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/pride/8347133/troye-sivan-responds-online-backlash-fans-gq-australia-interview |title=Troye Sivan Addresses Online Backlash From Fans: 'The Important Thing Is How You Respond' |work=Billboard|access-date=2018-04-30}}</ref> The song is a notable contrast from his earlier work, with ''Pitchfork'' commenting on his "assured" vocals and ''NPR Music'' describing it as "an infectious celebration of sexual desire".<ref name="auto1"/> ''NPR Music'' also notes the significance of the song and music video displaying confidence in Sivan's sexuality, writing "[i]t's not every day you see a young, skinny, queer kid get to be completely himself in a music video, and Sivan makes us want to dance along with him."<ref name="auto1"/> Sivan's first live performance of the song was on 20 January as the musical guest on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' in an episode hosted by [[Jessica Chastain]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/television/8094058/halsey-troye-sivan-chris-stapleton-saturday-night-live |title=Halsey, Troye Sivan & Chris Stapleton Are 2018's First 'Saturday Night Live' Performances |work=Billboard}}</ref> Sivan later confirmed that his new album would feature a collaboration with long-time friend [[Ariana Grande]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8215596/troye-sivan-ariana-grande-collaboration |title=Troye Sivan Confirms Collaboration With His 'Pop Queen' Ariana Grande |work=Billboard |accessdate=4 March 2018}}</ref> titled "[[Dance to This]]".<ref>{{cite news |last=Millar |first=Jake |title=Troye Sivan GQ Exclusive: "I've Made The Album I Always Wanted To Make" |url=https://www.gq.com.au/entertainment/music/troye+sivan+gq+exclusive+irve+made+the+album+i+always+wanted+to+make+,54441 |accessdate=14 April 2018 |work=GQ |date=13 April 2018}}</ref> "[[Bloom (Troye Sivan song)|Bloom]]" was released as the third single on 2 May 2018, following "[[The Good Side]]".<ref>{{cite news |last=Brandle |first=Lars |title=Troye Sivan's 'Bloom' is Here: Listen |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8449324/troye-sivan-bloom-lyric-video |accessdate=3 May 2018 |work=Billboard |date=3 May 2018}}</ref> That month, he announced that his second studio album is titled ''[[Bloom (Troye Sivan album)|Bloom]]'', while accompanying [[Taylor Swift]] as a guest performer at her concert in [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]] during her [[Taylor Swift's Reputation Stadium Tour|Reputation Stadium Tour]]. The album was released on 31 August 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8473068/troye-sivan-unleashed-bloom-stream-it-now|title=Troye Sivan Has Unleashed 'Bloom': Stream It Now|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Schneier |first=Matthew |date=10 May 2018 |title=Troye Sivan Is a New Kind of Pop Star: Here, Queer and Used to It |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/10/arts/music/troye-sivan-bloom.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=10 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=English |first=Laura |title=Troye Sivan Reveals New Album Release Date While On Stage With Taylor Swift |url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/troye-sivan-reveals-album-release-date-taylor-swift/ |accessdate=27 May 2018 |work=MusicFeeds Australia |date=21 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Close |first1=Paris |title=Troye Sivan Gives New Album 'Bloom' Release Date, Reveals Cover Artwork |url=http://popcrush.com/troye-sivan-bloom-release-date-cover-art/ |accessdate=27 May 2018 |work=Pop Crush |date=20 May 2018}}</ref> The album's final pre-release track, "Animal", was launched on August 9, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/troye-sivan-unleashes-animal-stream-it-now/ar-BBLGUGG?li=AA2qN5v|title=Troye Sivan Unleashes 'Animal': Stream It Now|website=Msn.com|access-date=2018-08-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8469404/troye-sivan-unleashes-animal-stream-it-now|title=Troye Sivan Unleashes 'Animal': Stream It Now|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-08-09}}</ref>
=== Music videos === Sivan's music videos frequently feature LGBTQ relationships between the characters. ''TRXYE''{{'}}s trilogy followed the narrative of two gay teenagers in a secret relationship while "Wild" featured Sivan with another male love interest. His music video for "Heaven ft. Betty Who" features footage of historical LGBTQ movements and couples, as well as sensual shots with him and an anonymous man with the running tagline "Without losing a piece of me, how do I get to Heaven?" and "If I'm losing a piece of me, maybe I don't want Heaven". The singer says these portrayals are important to him, especially when he considers his younger life when he remembers "such vivid memories of the few times I saw any type of LGBTQ relationship on TV or in music videos".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.kitchenerpost.ca/whatson-story/6955732-q-a-troye-sivan-on-coming-out-canadian-popstars/ |title=Q&A: Troye Sivan on coming out, Canadian popstars |last=Friend |first=David |date=9 November 2016 |work=Kitchener Post |accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
=== Acting === In 2007, Sivan starred as Oliver Twist in a production of ''[[Oliver!]]'' at the [[Regal Theatre]].<ref name="stm" /> In 2008, Sivan was cast in a West Australian short film, ''Betrand the Terrible''.<ref>{{cite news |last=Coyne |first=Yvette |title=Bertrand the Terrible – LINK funded film |url=http://www.fti.asn.au/blogs/production-support-report/2010/02/bertrand-the-terrible---link-f.php |accessdate=15 January 2014 |newspaper=Film & Television Institute (WA) Inc |date=16 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5r0skWmOp?url=http://www.fti.asn.au/blogs/production-support-report/2010/02/bertrand-the-terrible---link-f.php |archivedate=6 July 2010}}</ref> In February 2008, Sivan was cast as young [[Wolverine (character)|James Howlett]] in ''[[X-Men Origins: Wolverine]]''. Sivan got the part after videos of his telethon performance were posted on [[YouTube]], catching the attention of a Hollywood agent who contacted Sivan and asked him to send in an audition tape.<ref name="stm" /> Though [[Kodi Smit-McPhee]] was already cast for this role, he was unable to be a part of the film, due to his other film, ''[[The Road (2009 film)|The Road]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,23320029-16955,00.html |title=One for the road clears the path |last=Bodey |first=Michael |date=5 March 2008 |newspaper=[[The Australian]] |accessdate=15 January 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203152946/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,23320029-16955,00.html |archivedate=3 December 2008}}</ref> In July 2009, he auditioned successfully for the lead role in ''[[Spud (film)|Spud]]'', a film adaptation of [[Spud (novel)|the 2005 novel]] by South African author [[John van de Ruit]].<ref name="stn">{{cite web |url=http://www.troyesivan.com/news16_spudrole.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100215214424/http://www.troyesivan.com/news16_spudrole.html |archivedate=15 February 2010 |title=Troye plays lead role in Spud – The Movie |accessdate=2 February 2010 |date=2 February 2010 |website=Troyesivan.com}}</ref> Filming took place in South Africa from early March to mid-April 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Spud's Young Stars |url=http://www.screenafrica.com/news/film/434162.htm |work=Screen Africa |date=8 March 2010 |accessdate=24 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5pxZ2wsF3?url=http://www.screenafrica.com/news/film/434162.htm |archivedate=24 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=John |last=Van de Ruit |title=Icarus Allsorts |url=http://johnvanderuit.book.co.za/blog/2010/04/20/icarus-allsorts/ |work=John van de Ruit's blog at Book South Africa |date=20 April 2010 |accessdate=24 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5pxbp5CrW?url=http://johnvanderuit.book.co.za/blog/2010/04/20/icarus-allsorts/ |archivedate=24 May 2010}}</ref> The film was released in South Africa on 3 December 2010 and was later nominated for six [[South African Film and Television Awards|SAFTAs]], including a Best Lead Actor in a Feature Film nomination for Sivan.<ref name="safta">{{cite web |title=2011 SAFTAs: All The Winners |url=http://www.tvsa.co.za/user/blogs/viewblogpost.aspx?blogpostid=22376 |website=TVSA |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VbGGSrRk?url=http://www.tvsa.co.za/user/blogs/viewblogpost.aspx?blogpostid=22376 |archivedate=15 January 2015 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Sivan appeared in the West Australian season of [[Samuel Beckett]]'s absurdist play ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' which opened on 28 May 2010.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://thewest.com.au/news/australia/troye-on-stage-with-theatre-great-ng-ya-211428 |title=Troye on stage with theatre great |date=23 May 2010 |work=The West Australian|access-date=6 October 2017}}</ref> Sivan shared the role of "Boy" with Craig Hyde-Smith, alternating nights.<ref>{{cite news |title=Troye on stage with theatre great |first=Daniel |last=Hatch |url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/breaking/7281062/troye-on-stage-with-theatre-great/ |newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |page=3 |date=24 May 2010 |accessdate=24 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5pxoNqRIv?url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/breaking/7281062/troye-on-stage-with-theatre-great/ |archivedate=24 May 2010}}</ref> In June 2012, Sivan returned to South Africa to film ''Spud 2: The Madness Continues'', which was released in South Africa on 21 June 2013. Sivan also starred in the third film in the series, ''[[Spud 3: Learning to Fly]]'', released on 28 November 2014.
Sivan co-starred in the coming of age/coming out film ''[[Boy Erased]]'' (2018), opposite [[Lucas Hedges]], [[Xavier Dolan]], and [[Nicole Kidman]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://popcrush.com/troye-sivan-gay-conversion-therapy-movie-boy-erased/ |title=Troye Sivan to Star in Film About Gay Conversion Therapy |website=PopCrush|access-date=6 October 2017}}</ref>
=== YouTube === [[File:Tyler Oakley & Troye Sivan (14531885415).jpg|thumb|Oakley (left) and Sivan speaking at VidCon 2014]]
In September 2012, Sivan began creating [[video blog]]s on the video sharing site [[YouTube]], after having only sung on the site since 2007. At the time of posting his first vlog, Sivan had accumulated 27,000 subscribers in his five years since joining YouTube on 1 October 2007. As of April 2016, Sivan had over 4 million subscribers and over 243 million total views across his YouTube videos.<ref name="Social Blade" /> His YouTube channel is the third most subscribed channel in Australia, after HowToBasic and Planet Dolan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://socialblade.com/youtube/top/country/AU/mostsubscribed |title=Top 100 YouTubers in Australia Filtered by Subscribers – Socialblade Youtube Stats | Youtube Statistics |work=Social Blade |accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref>
A YouTube video Sivan made with fellow [[List of YouTubers|YouTuber]] [[Tyler Oakley]] titled "The 'Boyfriend' Tag" earned them a [[2014 Teen Choice Awards#Choice Web|Teen Choice Award]] in the "Choice Web Collaboration" category.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/teen-choice-awards-2014-winners-724423 |title=Teen Choice Awards: The Complete Winners List |last=Nordyke |first=Kimberly |date=10 August 2016 |work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=29 December 2016}}</ref>
== Artistry == Sivan's favourite artists include [[Amy Winehouse]], [[Taylor Swift]] and [[Lorde]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WFirSjxrWgo |title=Troye Sivan – Fans, Favorites + Fangirling |date=8 September 2015 |work=PopCrush |access-date = 11 April 2016}}</ref> MTV Artists also cites [[Michael Jackson]] and [[Frank Ocean]] as additional influences.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/troye-sivan-1/related-artists/?filter=influencedBy |title=Artist Influences for Troye Sivan |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420160336/http://www.mtv.com/artists/troye-sivan-1/related-artists/?filter=influencedBy |archive-date=20 April 2016 |website=MTV Artists |publisher=MTV |access-date = 11 April 2016}}</ref>
Sivan's music has been described as "layered electropop with constant tinges of EDM".<ref name="guardian">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/04/troye-sivan-blue-neighbourhood-review- |title=Troye Sivan: Blue Neighbourhood review – immaculate doses of three-minute emotion |date=3 December 2015 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref> His baritone voice<ref>{{cite web |url=https://singersavenue.tumblr.com/post/97199424787/troye-sivans-vocal-profile-vocal-type-baritone |title=SingersAvenue — Troye Sivan's Vocal Profile |last=SingersAvenue |website=SingersAvenue |access-date = 12 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elle.com/culture/music/a34570/troye-sivan-cross-gender-appeal/ |title=The Dreamy, Cross-Gender Appeal of Troye Sivan |date=3 March 2016 |website=ELLE |access-date = 12 April 2016}}</ref> has received widespread praise.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2014/09/05/something-to-tell-you-about-troye-sivans-trxye/ |title=Something to Tell You about Troye Sivan's 'TRXYE' |website=Yaledailynews.com |access-date = 12 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/album-reviews-jamie-woon-troye-sivan-and-ceelo-green-8211-after-the-zeitgeist-20151125-gl6km5.html |title=Album reviews: Jamie Woon, Troye Sivan and CeeLo Green – after the zeitgeist |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |access-date = 12 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/blue-neighbourhood-mw0002890150 |title=Blue Neighbourhood – Troye Sivan |website=AllMusic |access-date = 12 April 2016}}</ref> His work has been compared to Lorde's and Taylor Swift's.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2015/12/03/album-review-troye-sivan-blue-neighbourhood/FH2el2uyhLPiTMJBnPjp5N/story.html |title=Album review: Troye Sivan, 'Blue Neighbourhood' |last=Reed |first=James |date=3 December 2015 |work=The Boston Globe |access-date = 11 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/review/6785685/troye-sivan-blue-neighbourhood-album-review |title=Troye Sivan Shows Growth and Growing Pains on Debut 'Blue Neighbourhood': Album Review |website=Billboard |access-date = 12 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/latest-album-reviews-troye-sivan-coldplay-molly-ost-palms--ceelo-green/news-story/d4c668198035b7815536470dfa65274d |title=Latest Album Reviews: Troye Sivan, Coldplay, Molly OST, Palms & Ceelo Green |website=NewsComAu |access-date = 12 April 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== Sivan is openly gay. He came out publicly via a YouTube video on 7 August 2013. He came out to his family three years before his video was released.<ref>{{cite news |title=Troye Sivan Gay: Australian Actor Comes Out On YouTube |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/09/troye-sivan-gay_n_3733596.html |accessdate=15 January 2014 |newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=9 August 2013}}</ref> He lives with a mild form of [[Marfan syndrome]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://troyesivan.tumblr.com/post/41456927880/troye-have-you-ever-noticed-how-long-your-fingers |title=TROYE SIVAN |work=Tumblr |date=25 January 2013 |accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> Sivan is in a relationship with model Jacob Bixenman.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.papermag.com/troye-sivan-my-my-my-2524526154.html |title=Troye Sivan's 'My My My!' is a Liberated Anthem For Love (Watch) |date=11 January 2018 |work=PAPERMAG|access-date=15 January 2018}}</ref> He resides in [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="Cragg">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/17/troye-sivan-theres-power-in-living-openly-while-being-gay |title=Troye Sivan: 'There's power in living openly while being gay' |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=February 17, 2018 |accessdate=April 14, 2018 |last=Cragg |first=Michael}}</ref>
